name: 007 First Light
extraInfo: IOI has confirmed that Pro will have a quality and performance mode. Pro's quality mode will also use PSSR to run at 60fps, whereas base PS5 quality mode will (likely) run at 30fps. It will be interesting to see whether Pro's performance mode uses a less resource-intensive upscaler than PSSR to ensure a stable 60+fps. This would be particularly noteworthy as the September State of Play demo (running on base PS5 quality mode with no RT at 1440p) couldn't even sustain 30fps, and dipped as low as 18fps. Fortunately in late December, there was a delay from March to May 2026. This suggests IOI will take the necessary time to ensure proper optimization.

name: 28 Days TWS
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 run at a very stable 60fps and don't support HDR. While Pro renders at a slightly higher resolution, the difference in overall image quality is minimal. Shadows do however exhibit less flicker and certain assets (like workbenches) have more image stability on Pro.

name: 90s Extreme Skiing
extraInfo: Pro features 1.5x supersampling, resulting in a sharper image compared to base PS5. This also virtually eliminates shimmering, which is particularly noticeable in the distance. While the exact resolution and framerate haven't been confirmed, the more basic art style, as well as supersampling now being implemented, suggests it's likely rendering at the PSVR2 panel's highest resolution and refresh rate.

name: ActionCam: SC
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 run at a locked 60fps. However, you can significantly increase the FOV and it's here where Pro will have an easier time maintaining 60fps in more demanding scenes. Pro potentially has a slightly higher resolution than base PS5, but any difference is negligible - especially when the camera effects are toggled on.

name: Alan Wake 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1224p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a mostly stable 30fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a locked 40fps. Combines the RT of the quality mode with image settings of performance. Requires 120 Hz display.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR/FSR at a mostly stable 60fps (lows of 50fps) with no RT. Graphics settings of base PS5's quality mode (more foliage/better lighting etc).

extraInfo: Pro can toggle between PSSR and FSR for upscaling. FSR is less noisy and more 4K like in stills. PSSR looks sharper in motion with less artifacting. Differences are less obvious in quality mode as base resolution is 1224p (others look relatively soft regardless as 864p to 4K is a big jump). There's no RT on base PS5 and Pro's quality mode also has higher quality shadows, volumetric lighting and fog. All Pro modes have a more stable framerate than their base PS5 equivalent.

name: Albatroz
extraInfo: Pro can render up to 4K (1080p-4K DRS), compared to 1440p on base PS5 (900p-1440p DRS). Pro also uses Unreal Engine 5's TSR to upscale it final output, whereas base PS5 uses TAAU. The increased resolution and superior upscaler results in a much sharper image on Pro. While both consoles also target 60fps, Pro's framerate is more stable. PSSR as well as RT reflections, ambient occlusion and shadows were experimented with for Pro, but were ultimately not implemented due to time constraints.

name: Alien: Rogue Incursion
extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro run at 60fps and upscale to 4K. Pro however uses PSSR to upscale, whereas base PS5 (likely) uses TSR as it's a UE5 game. While the internal resolution before upscaling is unknown, the game is still very sharp on Pro which suggests that it's at least 1080p. Survios has also told Gaming Bolt that Pro has 'greater lighting/volumetric fog fidelity and more realistic reflections and surfacing'.

name: Anger Foot
extraInfo: Despite having the PS5 Pro Enhanced label on the PSN store, Free Lives has confirmed to me that Pro has no additional features or optimizations. Instead, Anger Foot has a singular mode on both base PS5 and Pro that runs at 1080p/60fps.

name: Anima: GOM I&II Remaster
pageTitle: Anima: Gate Of Memories I&II Remaster

modes.name: stability
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a steady 120fps.

extraInfo: While Pro's performance mode can reach up to 120fps, base PS5 is instead the regular 60fps. Performance mode might have a slightly lower resolution, but its difference is negligible even when switching between the 2 modes. This is most likely why performance is the default mode.

name: Anno 117: Pax Romana
extraInfo: Both base PS5 have the same resolution and framerate. However, Pro's RTGI implementation and the overall lighting is higher quality than base PS5. Pro also has some local light sources and reflections that aren't there on base PS5.

name: Apex Legends

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Targets 4K at 60fps with high visual quality. In practice, the fidelity/quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Targets 1440p at 120fps with reduced visual quality.

extraInfo: Pro's 2 modes are also on base PS5, but Pro hits the target framerate/resolution more often than their base PS5 equivalents, resulting in a far sharper/more fluid experience (especially in performance mode). Interestingly, Apex Legends doesn't follow the standard naming convention as there's no fidelity/graphics mode that would have been the 30fps mode in this case.

name: Arc Raiders
extraInfo: Embark stated via their Discord channel that both Pro and base PS5 use dynamic resolution scaling that can internally dip to as low as 720p. However, Pro can still reach a native 4K, whereas base PS5 can only render a maximum of 1600p (which then upscales to 4K). Pro also has improved global illumination, shadows, reflections, texture resolution/filtering, VFX and draw distance. Finally, Pro's framerate is more stable according to Push Square, although base PS5 only suffers from minor dips.

name: Ark: Survival Ascended
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination
extraInfo: Pro has a 30% FPS increase over base PS5 due to its PSSR implementation. While an improvement, base PS5's framerate hovers at around 30-35fps. Therefore, this 30% increase still won't produce a stable 60fps (will hover around 40-45fps, though can sometimes go over with frame gen) and there's no toggle to lock at 30fps/40fps for stability. Pro also uses UE5's virtual shadow maps over base PS5's cascade shadows for long-range and more accurate shadowing.

name: Arken Age

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4096p per eye at 60fps re-projected to 120fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 2240p per eye at 90fps native (no-reprojection).

extraInfo: VitruviusVR recommend Pro's performance mode in the settings menu, likely due to the native motion. Base PS5's resolutions are 2432p in quality mode and 2048p in performance mode (framerates remain the same).

name: Arknights: Endfield

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at an unstable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K DRS (likely) at an unstable 60fps (see extra info).

extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro have the same quality/performance mode options, but in regards to image quality, even the difference between Pro quality mode and base PS5 performance mode is minimal. Image quality looks great with sharp/stable RT regardless of console/mode - at most, base PS5's alpha effects can look a little more pixelated during combat. Framerate is however a different story. Regardless of console/mode, it can dip significantly after the opening section and VRR has been forcibly disabled. Performance mode should therefore be used to hit 60fps as much as possible.

name: Arma Reforger

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1944p to 4K FSR 1 at a nearly locked 30fps. Better ambient occlusion and cloud quality compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K FSR 1 at a relatively unstable 60fps. Doesn't have fidelity mode's shadows on terrain surfaces/contact shadows.

extraInfo: Base PS5 is exactly the same, but at 1620p and 1080p respectively. Performance mode has a decent amount of screen tearing. You can add an FPS counter to the HUD.

name: Asphalt Legends

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K native at up to 120fps. Usually around 90fps with VRR during racing.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: DRS that reaches up to native 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode's dynamic resolution scaling doesn't dip very far from 4K in order to maintain 120fps. It's near-impossible to tell a difference from normal viewing distances unless looking at the modes side-by-side. Base PS5 has the same modes, however its performance mode looks noticeably blurrier/1440p-like and its quality mode averages around 10-15fps less (lots of time at 65-75fps and with possible short dips into the mid 50s during effects-heavy crashes).

name: Assassin's Creed Mirage
extraInfo: Through PSSR, Pro combines the 4K resolution, better shadows/reflections, higher texture resolution, and improved draw distance seen in the base PS5's 30fps quality mode, with the 60fps seen in base PS5's performance mode. Pro's framerate is also a nearly locked 60fps and more stable than base PS5's performance mode.

name: Assassin's Creed Shadows
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination and reflections

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Around 1584p-1656p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a basically locked 30fps. Has both RT reflections and RTGI throughout open world. Higher quality draw distances, foliage density, shadows, textures, hair quality etc than performance mode.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Around 1440p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a stable 40fps with RT reflections (PSSR only) and RTGI (both upscalers). Graphical settings straddle between quality and performance modes (shadows of performance mode, hair strands of quality mode etc).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Around 1080p DRS to 4K TAAU/PSSR at a stable 60fps (lows of low 50s). No RT reflections, but RTGI remains throughout the world.

extraInfo: You can toggle between PSSR and TAAU as the upscaler. PSSR is a little softer, but much more stable with less aliasing/shimmer. TAAU's foliage/SSR is especially grainy and all of these issues are exacerbated in motion. PSSR fails to hit target framerate in performance mode as often (usually around 4-8fps fewer when it does drop), but still remains in the VRR window. RTGI is far more important to image quality than RT reflections. Base PS5's performance mode only has RTGI in the hideout, making Pro's performance mode a generational leap due to the improved lighting across the map. There's also no RT reflections on base PS5.

name: Astro Bot
extraInfo: Pro runs at 1368p-1872p DRS to 4K PSSR, with a locked 60fps, and is more often in the higher bounds of the DRS. Despite Pro's DRS having a lower base resolution than base PS5, Pro's PSSR upscaling is cleaner/sharper with less aliasing compared to base PS5's TAA. PSSR is however slightly noisier (especially SSR) and more unstable, but this isn't particularly visible at normal viewing distances.

name: Atomfall
extraInfo: Pro has DRS but can render at native 4K with a locked 60fps, whereas base PS5 renders a maximum of 1800p and has a less stable framerate. However, both can dip to 1440p and neither hit their top resolution most of the time. All versions are also poorly aliased (even PC), so resolution differences are less noticeable compared to other games because there's so much shimmer/jaggies regardless. There's also low resolution surfaces and very poor SSR (equivalent to PC low settings) that exacerbate the shimmer. Finally, the overkill AO (including the RT) overly silhouettes the image (especially characters) on all consoles and can't be turned off.

name: Avatar: Pandora Frontiers
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR at a mostly stable 60fps.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Sharper than quality pro (1512p-1800p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR) but at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Visual quality downgraded compared to quality but now at a locked 40fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lowest visual quality. 720p-936p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR at a nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: All modes can use either PSSR or FSR3 for upscaling to 4K. FSR is less noisy/unstable and looks sharper in stills, however PSSR is both sharper and clearer in motion (where most of the gameplay will be). PSSR works best with the quality 30fps mode due to its highest internal DRS. Quality, balanced and performance are all the legacy modes from base PS5 (FSR only), but will run at the higher DRS bounds (1800p for quality etc) more often, with a more stable framerate, due to Pro's extra power.

name: Avowed
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p-4K DRS to 4K TSR at a basically locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1440p-1800p DRS to 4K TSR at a basically locked 40fps. Visual quality mainly of performance mode except foliage GI).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1620p to 4K at a basically locked 60fps. Lower quality graphics settings (check extra info).

extraInfo: *All tech info is based off The Outer Worlds 2. However, as both games were developed simultaneously by Obsidian with Unreal Engine 5 and share a similar scope/genre, TOW2 provides a good baseline of expectations until Avowed's release. At which point this page will be updated with bespoke Avowed analysis - 'Obsidian has removed the bad PSSR implementation seen at launch and reverted back to TSR, which results in better performance gains, less noisy RT and a sharper image on Pro. Performance mode has less, more static foliage (at close distances) and lower quality (and therefore less realistic) UE5 Lumen/Virtual Shadow Maps. The lower internal resolution also leads to a noticeably softer/less stable image. Base PS5 has slightly worse framerate stability and internal resolutions compared to the equivalent mode on Pro, which leads to more instability/breakup - especially in performance mode.'

name: Bad Cheese
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 have a singular mode that runs at a locked 60fps with no HDR support. Both consoles also render a very 4K-like image, with only certain assets (the huge cobwebs etc, which look the exact same on both consoles) looking more jagged. If there is a resolution increase on Pro, it's indistinguishable during general gameplay.

name: Baldur's Gate 3

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K native at a nearly locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's performance mode looks better than even base PS5's quality mode due to upscalers used. PSSR is a little bit softer than base PS5's FSR, but much more stable with less artifacting/flickering. This instability is especially noticeable with assets in motion, such as moving shadows. Pro also has an approx 10% higher framerate, so manages to reach 60fps more often than base PS5 (especially important in later acts where base PS5 is particularly unstable). Finally, Pro can also run split screen at either 30fps or 60fps, compared to just 30fps on base PS5.

name: Banishers: New Eden

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K FSR at a stable 30fps/40fps on 60 Hz and 120 Hz screens respectively.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K FSR (lower internal dynamic resolution scaling than quality mode) at up to 120fps (usually averaging around 90fps).

extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro have a quality and performance mode with the same framerate targets. Pro quality mode maintains a stable 40fps more often. Neither performance mode hits 120fps most of the time, but Pro performance mode achieves it far more often in general gameplay and averages around 25fps more than base PS5 mode in like-for-like scenes. Base PS5 performance mode can dip to 60fps more often and only really reaches 120fps when looking up at the sky. While exact figures are unknown, Pro has a higher internal dynamic resolution scaling compared to base PS5's equivalent mode, which leads to a sharper (though still not 4K-sharp) looking image.

name: Battlefield 6

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1296p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps (quick 1-2fps dips in more demanding scenes).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at usually around 100-110fps. Lower quality shadows/lighting/occlusion (GTAO instead of SSGI), terrain, SSR, and LODs.

extraInfo: Base PS5 balanced mode has similar DRS/framerate to Pro. However, it uses Pro performance mode's inferior GTAO compared to Pro's SSGI, resulting in less realistic lighting/occlusion. Base PS5 performance mode uses GTAO, has lower DRS (1080p-1224p) and also runs at a lower 80-95fps compared to Pro performance mode. Base PS5 also uses FSR to upscale, however, Pro's PSSR creates a sharper 4K-like image with greater detail outside of foliage, which can look softer. While both Pro and base PS5 performance modes have worse visual settings, cutbacks are worse on base PS5. Menus are 30fps and cutscenes are capped at 60fps in all modes. In REDSEC, the DRS and performance mode framerate on both consoles are slightly lower than previously stated due to the increased BR scale.

name: Beneath
extraInfo: Camel 101 have confirmed that they're targeting 4K and 60fps on both base PS5 and Pro. They've also confirmed that Pro will utilize PSSR for 'enhanced visuals'. This potentially means that PSSR is doing a better job of creating a 4K-like image than base PS5's upscaler, or could simply mean that PSSR is using a higher internal resolution than what's on base PS5 due to Pro's extra power. We'll find out closer to the game's late 2025 launch.

name: Biped
extraInfo: Biped has no display options, so features like an 120fps mode aren't available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro also renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The resolution difference can be quite noticeable on assets like railings, where there's more jaggies on base PS5.

name: Biped 2
extraInfo: *Biped 2 doesn't have any tech info out there yet, but the following Biped 1 information provides a good baseline of expectations - 'Biped has no display options, so features like an 120fps mode aren't available. However, Pro at least maintains a locked 60fps. Pro also renders a 1440p image compared to base PS5's more 1080p-like image. The resolution difference can be quite noticeable on assets like railings, where there's more jaggies on base PS5.'

name: Black Desert

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a mostly locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Black Desert (likely) doesn't have Pro enhancements yet despite confirmation that Pearl Abyss are working on it. At the very least, the fidelity mode's 60fps will be more stable on Pro due to the extra horsepower. However, both modes suffer from severe pop in that includes texture quality and actual assets. This makes the image rather poor regardless of mode and can't be fixed on console.

name: Black Myth: Wukong
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1620p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1512p to 4K PSSR at a very stable 40fps on 120 Hz screens or around 45fps on 60 Hz. Lower resolution shadows than quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p average DRS to 1800p PSSR, with no frame-gen at a very stable 60fps, but no Lumen GI.

modes.name: legacy performance
modes.description: Original performance mode until October 2025. 1296p FSR3 and frame-gen used (30fps internal) to target a still unstable 60ps. Worse shadows/filtering than new performance mode.

extraInfo: Base PS5's legacy performance mode is only 1080p and like Pro, also uses frame generation. Due to frame-gen, the quality/balanced modes on both consoles have less input lag and therefore feel more responsive, despite fewer frames. Pro's PSSR offers a far clearer image (albeit a little noisier) than FSR2, which base PS5 uses in its balanced (1296p internal to 1620p) and quality (1440p internal to 4K) modes. Like Pro, Performance mode is also sharper on base PS5 (1080p average DRS to 1440p FSR2) than the legacy mode. However, the new performance mode's lack of Lumen GI can result in poor/flat ps3-quality lighting indoors on both consoles, but outdoor image quality can vary. Base PS5 has worse LODs, AO, and shadow quality across all modes.

name: Blades Of Fire
extraInfo: Both PS5 consoles cap the framerate at 60fps. On Pro, there's dynamic resolution scaling that ranges from 1080p-4K native before being upscaled to 4K PSSR. With 1080p being the lowest internal resolution value, PSSR is still able to reconstruct an excellent 4K image in the most demanding areas.

name: BlazBlue Entropy Effect X
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off the demo and is subject to change for the final release - 'Both Pro and base PS5 run at a stable 120fps (at least in the early stages) and render a very 4K-like image. However, there are some menus where the framerate does drop and it's here where we see a difference between consoles (around 100fps on Pro and 70fps on base PS5). Presumably, this means in later stages where there's more going on, Pro should be able to maintain 120fps more often than base PS5.'

name: Borderlands 4
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen global illumination and reflections

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1152p+ DRS to 4K at a basically locked 30fps. Improved/more stable Lumen GI and reflections over performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 864p-1152p DRS to 4K at a mostly locked 60fps (short 1-2fps dips) with a fresh save (check extra info).

extraInfo: While Pro can maintain 60fps in performance mode, all consoles (even Xbox) suffer from memory leak, which results in progressively worse framerates. By the hour mark, Pro's framerate hovers at 40fps. In order to fix it, restarting from the main menu roughly every 30 minutes is needed. This leak happens in quality mode too, but isn't as bad due to the 30fps cap. Despite not having the Pro Enhanced label on the PSN store, BL4 is. Firstly, the HUD/menus are 4K in both modes on Pro, but only 1080p on base PS5. Base PS5's internal resolution is also around 746p-810p in performance mode and can dip below the 48fps VRR floor even with a fresh save, whereas Pro is 864p-900p at a stable 60fps in the same scenes. Pro also has boosted draw distance/shading in both modes, but that's only on base PS5's quality mode (that dips to as low as 720p). Finally, there's no motion blur options, which is fine for performance mode but unacceptable for a 30fps quality mode.

name: Call Of Duty: Black Ops 6

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly locked 60fps, or typically around 70-90fps with VRR. Improved global illumination (biggest improvement), ambient occlusion, reflections and 2-4x shadow resolution compared to 120 Hz mode.

modes.name: 120 Hz refresh rate
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a relatively stable 120fps. Graphics settings the same as base PS5's fidelity mode that runs at 60fps.

extraInfo: The anti-lag VRR implementation in Pro's fidelity mode (120 Hz refresh rate toggled off) means it actually has lower input latency than the 120 Hz mode, despite fewer frames. An improved PSSR implementation also arrived in a patch that significantly reduced artifacting/white dots in some areas, although they're still somewhat visible on rare occasions. Splitscreen multiplayer is now a locked 60fps (mid 50s on base PS5).

name: Call Of Duty: Black Ops 7

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a mostly locked 60fps, or typically around 70-90fps with VRR. Improved global illumination (biggest improvement), ambient occlusion, reflections and 2-4x shadow resolution compared to 120 Hz mode.

modes.name: 120 Hz refresh rate
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a relatively stable 120fps. Graphics settings the same as base PS5's fidelity mode that runs at 60fps.

extraInfo: *All tech information on the page is based off Black Ops 6's enhancements as there's been no analsysis done by a trusted secondary source like Digital Foundry at the time of writing. Fortunately, B06 and B07 were developed simultaneously by the same teams. B06 therefore provides a good baseline of expectations, especially as B07's beta shows very similar results - 'The anti-lag VRR implementation in Pro's fidelity mode (120 Hz refresh rate toggled off) means it actually has lower input latency than the 120 Hz mode, despite fewer frames. Splitscreen multiplayer is now a locked 60fps (mid 50s on base PS5). Base PS5 120 Hz mode is less stable than Pro's and also runs at a lower, more 1008p-1080p resolution. Base PS5 fidelity mode has a similar resolution, but still looks less stable due to Pro's good PSSR implementation.'

name: Carmageddon: Rogue Shift
extraInfo: While 34BigThings have already begun their marketing cycle just a few days into 2026, they've confirmed to me on Jan 5 that they're not sharing technical information like Pro enhancements just yet, but an announcement regarding it will come 'soon'. I'll be sure to update this page as soon as any technical information is made public.

name: Carmen Sandiego
extraInfo: *Technical information is from anecdotal message board remarks by gamers who purchased Carmen Sandiego, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing - 'The only difference between base PS5 and Pro is framerate - base PS5 is 60fps whereas Pro is 120fps.'

name: Chess Infinity
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen hardware-based lighting, reflections and shadows

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p-4K native DRS at a mostly locked 30fps with all RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TSR at a mostly locked 60fps with all RT.

extraInfo: Pro uses superior hardware-based RT compared to software-based RT on base PS5 (less breakup/clearer reflections etc). Performance can dip depending on scene complexity, which will then kick in the dynamic resolution scaling.

name: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination/reflections and Nanite virtual shadow maps with RT

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1552p DRS to 4K TSR at a locked 30fps. Both software-based Lumen GI and reflections, as well as RT shadows via Nanite (though not all shadows receive RT for accurate diffuse).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1062p-1386p DRS to 1800p TSR at a nearly locked 60fps. Lower quality Lumen GI/reflections compared to quality mode and no RT shadows.

extraInfo: Quality mode has a noticeably sharper image with less shimmer/breakup in hair. Performance mode can dip below 60fps, but stays well within the VRR window and only lasts a couple seconds. Base PS5 also has DRS and its internal resolution can go as low as 720p (performance) and 900p (quality), leading to far more shimmer/breakup. Real-time cutscenes are an uneven 30fps regardless of mode or hardware (even PC) and the early FMV cutscenes have visible macroblocking.

name: Code Violet
extraInfo: TeamKill Media have confirmed via X that base PS5 will run at 4K/30fps, whereas Pro is 4K/60fps. It's highly that the 4K output is upscaled from a currently unknown internal resolution, but this is already a large jump via the framerate regardless. Other information such what UE5 Lumen features are used etc will also have to wait until closer to its January 2026 launch.

name: Control: Ultimate Edition

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR/TAA, with RT, at a locked 30fps. Or usually around 45-55fps with VRR (depending on upscaler).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR/TAA, with no RT, at a very stable 60fps. Or usually around 80-100fps with VRR (depending on upscaler).

extraInfo: While Pro can choose between PSSR and TAA for upscaling, base PS5 is TAA only. PSSR delivers smoother edges, better hair/vegetation quality, less ghosting, and sharper/smoother motion clarity with less shimmer/pixel crawl. However, PSSR carries a higher compute cost - typically running 5-15 fps lower than TAA when framerates are unlocked. TAA is also sharper/more stable in stills. Both upscalers ensure a locked 30/60fps though and when unlocked, both still run higher than base PS5 (around 70fps in typical gameplay for performance mode and only up to 40fps in graphics mode). Finally, Pro has better SSR (in performance mode) and texture/shadow filtering compared to base PS5 (which is also 1440p to 4K TAA in both modes).

name: Crimson Desert
extraInfo: Pearl Abyss have confirmed to me that Pro enhancements won't be discussed until next year. However, when looking at the officially released Pro gameplay of Crimson Desert, both a 4K output and 60fps seem very likely. A 30fps mode with improved graphical settings (better open-world LODs etc) would also be a great option for people who don't mind 30fps in third-person titles.

name: Cronos: The New Dawn

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1296p-1440p DRS to 4K TSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p-1242p DRS to 4K TSR at a somewhat unstable 60fps (see extra info).

extraInfo: Pro performance mode dips to 45-57fps with effect-heavy scenes (fire etc) and traversal stutters, but maintains close to 60fps in general gameplay. Base PS5 also has a performance mode (864p-1026p DRS) and quality mode (1080p-1440p DRS) where the only difference between them is resolution (inc volumetrics). Base PS5 quality mode is also a locked 30fps, but its 60fps is more unstable than Pro (by about 10fps) and dips more often in general gameplay (though still close to 60fps most of the time). All info is taken from DF's analysis before Cronos received the Pro Enhanced tag on the PSN Store. However, considering the limited updates and Pro's improvements, it's likely that this tag was just not there at launch and DF's analysis matches Cronos's current performance.

name: Crystal Of Atlan
extraInfo: Nuverse has confirmed that Pro uses PSSR to upscale to a 4K image. This isn't possible on base PS5 as PSSR is an AI upscaler.

name: CyubeVR
resolution: 8K textures with dynamic foveated rendering for the rest of the image
extraInfo: Pro has increased distance for maximum LOD quality of the landscape and anything the player has built on it. Pro also has higher LOD quality for trees so changes are less noticeable from a distance.

name: Days Gone Remastered

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 2880p (5K) at a locked 30fps or around 35fps with VRR. Supersamples down to 2160p (4K) on 4K displays for the sharpest image of any mode on any console.

modes.name: enhanced
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps or around 70fps with VRR. As sharp as the native PS4 app playing on PS5 with no checkerboard rendering artifacts.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 40fps, or around 55fps with VRR. PSSR used for aliasing, not upscaling. Sharper than enhanced mode but less sharp than quality mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1800p to 4K at a nearly locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Slightly blurrier than PS4 app on PS5, but has higher detailed LODs/no CBR artifacts.

extraInfo: Compared to PS4, the biggest upgrade is the new sky simulation, which renders more accurate sunlight and darker nights. There's also increased foliage/draw distance (past PC max settings), as well as higher resolution shadows/textures, improved SSR/SSGI and more vibrant general lighting (sub-surface scattering/key lights). PSSR in enhanced mode is noisier in distant assets and foliage can blur when swaying, but looks much better in motion. VRR can be used in all modes and gives Pro's balanced mode the most significant advantage over its base PS5 equivalent. Base PS5 performance mode is so blurry that it looks worse than even the native PS4 app.

name: Dead Island 2
extraInfo: The framerate is a locked 60fps on both consoles, but Pro improves shadow quality, motion blur, texture filtering and depth of field over base PS5. Pro also has longer draw distances and contact shadows on all objects/lights. Pro uses DRS, but the resolution is above 2000p for the majority of gameplay, including often at native 4K. It can drop down as low as 1620p (technically lower than base PS5's fixed 1728p), but this is very rare and only lasts a couple of seconds.

name: Dead Rising Deluxe
extraInfo: Pro uses RT reflections, which are a huge improvement over base PS5's screen space reflections due to the shopping mall setting (storefront windows etc). While both base PS5 and Pro run at native 4K, Pro also has a locked 60fps even with RT reflections, whereas base PS5 dips into the low 50s in the most demanding scenarios. This is most likely why base PS5 doesn't support RT.

name: Death Stranding 1: DC

modes.name: prioritize quality
modes.description: 4K native at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: 1440p-4K DRS at a very nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: *All technical information is based off Death Stranding 2 as no Pro analysis exists at the time of writing. However, considering this Pro enhancement came shortly after DS2's launch, the sequel provides a good baseline of expectations until a full analysis can be done - 'Pro's performance and quality modes look nearly identical despite a 2x in framerate. Both Pro and base PS5 performance modes run in an 120 Hz container, resulting in less input lag. Outside of base PS5's higher DRS (1800p-4K) in quality mode, Pro performance mode matches its graphical settings (distant terrain detail/geometry, shadows, AO & texture LODs). Base PS5 performance mode's 1260p-1800p DRS can be noticeably blurrier, with more image instability/shimmer/fizzle as well as worse reflections/shadows/draw distance than all the other modes.'

name: Death Stranding 2: OTB

modes.name: prioritize quality
modes.description: 4K native at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: 1440p-4K DRS at a very nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's performance and quality modes look nearly identical despite a 2x in framerate. Both Pro and base PS5 performance modes run in an 120 Hz container, resulting in less input lag. Outside of base PS5's higher DRS (1800p-4K) in quality mode, Pro performance mode matches its graphical settings (distant terrain detail/geometry, shadows, AO & texture LODs). Base PS5 performance mode's 1260p-1800p DRS can be noticeably blurrier, with more image instability/shimmer/fizzle as well as worse reflections/shadows/draw distance than all the other modes.

name: Delta Force
extraInfo: Delta Force doesn't currently have Pro enhancements. However, the developers have confirmed that one is coming with its next seasonal update. This will provide PSSR support to 'deliver sharper visuals and greater stability'.

name: Demon's Souls

modes.name: PS5 pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K PSSR with improved shadows at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: cinematic
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 4K native at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1440p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: While the native 4K in base PS5's cinematic (quality) mode is a little sharper than PS5 Pro mode, it's also far more noisy, more aliased, and less temporally stable than the 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K PSSR in the Pro mode, which therefore has the better image quality despite the lower internal resolution. PS5 Pro mode also has improved shadows and a locked 60fps, therefore making the legacy cinematic/performance modes redundant.

name: Diablo IV

modes.name: enhanced visuals
modes.description: DRS that reaches up to 4K native at 30fps. RT shadows and reflections. Improves quality of fur, hair and fog compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60fps. No RT.

extraInfo: Enhanced visuals mode hovers around 45-50fps with VRR. It therefore won't always prevent stutter as the framerate can dip below the 48fps VRR threshold on PlayStation. Fortunately, Pro's enhanced visuals mode still has a higher resolution, improved ambient occlusion and higher quality RT reflections compared base PS5's equivalent mode.

name: Divinity: Original Sin 2 DE

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: While both modes are capped at 60fps, quality mode mode provides a noticeable resolution increase and at a very stable 60fps. Performance mode should only be chosen to (hopefully) guarantee 60fps in later, more demanding areas.

name: Doom: The Dark Ages
extraInfo: Pro drops frames in more demanding open arenas, but stays within the VRR window (mid 50s) and is still generally more stable than base PS5. Base PS5 renders between 1008p-1440p DRS (usually around 1080p) compared to the 1260p-1800p DRS (usually around 1620p) on Pro. With Pro's lower bounds only being in these more open arenas. RTGI quality is the same on both, but Pro has a slightly better draw distance and anisotropic filtering. Variable rate shading is used on every console (Xbox too), resulting in a blurrier image than the resolution would suggest. VRS is therefore least noticeable on Pro. Finally, RT reflections and path tracing are PC only.

name: Dragon Age: The Veilguard

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Roughly 1296p to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 30fps with RTAO.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Roughly 864p-1296p DRS to 1800p PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps with RTAO. Can flicker a lot/look very aliased due to low base resolution.

extraInfo: Base PS5 uses FSR instead of PSSR, where it's 1080p to 1800p FSR (fidelity) and 864p to 1440p FSR (performance). Base PS5 is a lot softer, but less flickering/aliasing can make foliage/reflections look better compared to Pro. You can see the differences in the background of the menu when toggling between the modes (AO on foliage etc).

name: Dragon's Dogma 2

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at an unevenly paced 30fps. Around 40-50fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at a relatively locked 60fps (lows of low 50s).

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: 720p to 4K PSSR at a mostly locked 60fps. Usually around 70-85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: All modes can toggle RTGI on/off. When enabled, the framerate is around 10fps fewer than the values stated above. Due to PSSR, RT is noisy/aliased and looks worse as the internal resolution lowers in subsequent modes. This exacerbation is also true with regular occlusion, although PSSR still creates a sharper image and significantly improves ghosting, texture detail and material quality compared to FSR on base PS5. Pro also hits its target framerate much more often than base PS5 in all modes.

name: Dreams Of Another
extraInfo: Q-Games has confirmed that Pro will have 'detailed point cloud visuals'. Pro will also render at 1440p compared to 1080p on base PS5. Both consoles use 60 Hz to 120 Hz reprojection in the optional VR mode (exclusive to PSVR2).

name: Dying Light 2: Stay Human
rtTypes: Ray traced shadows, reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at a locked 30 FPS with no RT. Better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a locked 30 FPS with RT. Now with increased base resolution (1440p) and better contact shadows compared to base PS5.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at nearly locked 60 FPS with no RT. Increased base resolution (1512p) compared to base PS5.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K with no RT and with VRR, up to 120 FPS. Increased base resolution (1440p), better contact shadows, spot shadows, and fog quality compared to base PS5.

extraInfo: All of Pro's modes also have improved global illumination, screen space reflections (except quality mode due to RT) and sub surface scattering compared to their equivalent base PS5 mode.

name: Dying Light: The Beast

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1944p-4K DRS at a locked 30fps. Improved shadows/lighting/LODs (foliage etc) compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1260p-1512p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps, or around 65fps (outdoors) and 80fps (indoors) with VRR.

extraInfo: The main difference between Pro and base PS5 is resolution. In performance mode, base PS5's DRS is 972p-1080p compared to Pro's DRS floor of 1260p. In quality mode, base PS5 is 1620p-1728p, whereas Pro's floor is 1944p. All modes lock to their framerate target except for quick 1fps dips during cutscene camera changes. However, base PS5 averages around 5-10fps higher than Pro with VRR (likely due to lower DRS). Before launch, Techland said The Beast will take Pro enhancements much further than Dying Light 2. However, it doesn't even have DL2's balanced mode or any of its 3 RT features. Hopefully, these come in a patch - resolution bumps are nice, but it's a far cry from what Techland promised. Unfortunately, their 11 week roadmap only mentions RT for PC which suggests the wait will be even longer for Pro.

name: Dynasty Warriors: Origins

modes.name: native 4K
modes.description: 4K at a very unstable 60fps (dips into low 50s, which is in VRR window).

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1512p-4K DRS at a nearly locked 60fps (can dip into high 50s, which is comfortably in VRR window).

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1440p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Prioritize graphics mode's DRS averages around 1700p during actual gameplay and the framerate can dip into high 50s. Native 4K mode barely hits 60fps, but at least stays within the VRR window as it's usually around the low 50s during combat.

name: EA College Football 25
rtTypes: GIBS (EA's own global illumination - hardware ray tracing for indirect lighting)
extraInfo: Pro removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes on base PS5 for just one mode. Pro's PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5's resolution mode and there's now 3D grass in gameplay, on more zoomed in cameras. However, PSSR also causes assets like crowd handrails to be more unstable. Pro's cutscenes/instant replays are now 60fps like in base PS5's performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps. Finally, the GIBS RT implementation seems unchanged.

name: EA College Football 26
rtTypes: GIBS (EA's own global illumination - hardware ray tracing for indirect lighting)
extraInfo: CFB 26 on Pro provides the same upgrades over base PS5 that CFB 25 had. Pro removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes on base PS5 for just one mode. Pro's PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5's resolution mode and there's now 3D grass in gameplay, on more zoomed in cameras. However, PSSR also causes assets like crowd handrails to be more unstable. Pro's cutscenes/instant replays are now 60fps like in base PS5's performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps. Finally, the GIBS RT implementation seems unchanged.

name: EA Sports FC 25
extraInfo: Pro combines base PS5's 'resolution' and 'enhanced visuals' modes into just one default mode. Pro sometimes renders an even sharper image than base PS5's resolution mode, while maintaining enhanced visuals mode's RTAO on pitch lighting/kits etc. Pro's cutscenes are now also 60fps, as opposed to 30fps on base PS5.

name: EA Sports FC 26
extraInfo: FC 26 provides the same Pro enhancements that were seen in last year's FC 25. Pro combines base PS5's 'resolution' and 'enhanced visuals' modes into just one default mode. Pro sometimes renders an even sharper image than base PS5's resolution mode, while maintaining enhanced visuals mode's RTAO on pitch lighting/kits etc. Pro's cutscenes are now also 60fps, as opposed to 30fps on base PS5.

name: EA Sports UFC 5
extraInfo: Pro's resolution during gameplay is slightly higher than base PS5. Pro also renders KO replays at 60fps instead of base PS5's 30fps. However, other cutscenes like ring entrances remain at 30fps on both consoles.

name: Empire Of The Ants
extraInfo: Base PS5 uses dynamic resolution scaling, which can have a higher internal resolution than Pro as it ranges from 1400p-1600p to 4K TSR, but only runs at 30fps compared to Pro's locked 60fps. Pro's fixed internal resolution of 1440p is also high enough that there's barely a difference between consoles once UE5's TSR is implemented.

name: Enlisted

modes.name: high quality
modes.description: 1920p to 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: high performance
modes.description: 1620p to 4K PSSR at a stable 120fps.

extraInfo: Pro's high performance mode now hits a solid 120fps, whereas base PS5's version is usually around 90fps with a lower 1440p internal resolution. Pro also has higher quality shadows, improved Global Illumination and due to PSSR, the overall image quality/clarity has improved.

name: Entropy Survivors

modes.name: default
modes.description: 4K at 60fps with no RT.

modes.name: ray tracing
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Pro's default mode (and base PS5's singular mode) run at 4K/60fps. However, Pro can exclusively toggle on RTGI for better lighting at the expense of slightly lower resolution. While the resolution dip is noticeable, Pro still renders a very 4K-like image with RT. At least in the early stages, both Pro modes and base PS5 run at a locked 60fps. Presumably, if there are some framerate dips in later, more chaotic stages, Pro should also maintain 60fps more often due to the extra horsepower.

name: Everspace 2
extraInfo: Despite Everspace 2 being one of the earliest games to be mentioned for Pro support, it still isn't Pro enhanced as of August 2025. The last update came in early 2025, when Rockfish told a Redditor that they were still trying to acquire a PS5 Pro dev kit. These were quite rare at the time, so Rockfish couldn't provide a timeframe for a patch. Hopefully, this situation changes soon and Everspace 2 receives its Pro enhancements before 2026.

name: F1 24
rtTypes: Ray traced dynamic diffuse global illumination, ambient occlusion, shadows and reflections

modes.name: 8K
modes.description: 4K to 8K TAAU at a locked 30fps. Gameplay has all RT, including shadows. Requires an 8K TV as it can't be down-sampled.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR. A locked 60fps with all RT in gameplay except shadows.

modes.name: 120 Hz performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU. Mostly at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Base PS5's quality mode has no RT during gameplay, whereas Pro's quality mode has 3/4 RT which dramatically improves realism. Pro even brings back RT shadows for cutscenes (which are now at 40fps, instead of base PS5's 30fps) and replays. Base PS5's quality mode resolution is 1800p-4K DRS, yet Pro's PSSR very nearly matches its sharpness despite being at 1080p-1440p DRS. Base PS5 has no 8K mode and its 120 Hz performance mode is also usually at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p.

name: F1 25
rtTypes: Ray traced dynamic diffuse global illumination, ambient occlusion, shadows and reflections

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: 4K to 8K TAAU at a locked 60fps with only RT DDGI in gameplay. Cutscenes/replays have all RT, but at 40fps. Requires an 8K TV as it can't be down-sampled.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR. A locked 60fps with all RT in gameplay except shadows.

modes.name: 120 Hz performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU. Mostly at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: *The biggest change from F1 24 to F1 25 is the 8K resolution mode. Whereas F1 24's gameplay included all RT, but ran at 8K/30fps, F1 25 only includes DDGI, but runs at 60fps whilst keeping 24's version for cutscenes/replays etc. Otherwise, the rest of the F1 24 info remains true - 'Base PS5's quality mode has no RT during gameplay, whereas Pro's quality mode has 3/4 RT which dramatically improves realism. Pro even brings back RT shadows for cutscenes (which are now at 40fps, instead of base PS5's 30fps) and replays. Base PS5's quality mode resolution is 1800p-4K DRS, yet Pro's PSSR very nearly matches its sharpness despite being at 1080p-1440p DRS. Base PS5 has no 8K mode and its 120 Hz performance mode is also usually at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p.'

name: Faaast Penguin
extraInfo: The only display setting is a brightness slider. However, Pro has a locked framerate that runs within an 120 Hz container to improve input lag (base PS5 is only at at 60 Hz). Pro could potentially render below native 4K sometimes, but it would only be for a very short duration, with dips would be so minor that FP still has a 4K-like image.

name: Fantasy Life I: TGWST
pageTitle: Fantasy Life I: The Girl Who Steals Time

modes.name: standard
modes.description: 4K at up to 120fps (usually around 85-100fps)

modes.name: enhanced graphics
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps with enhanced graphical settings like GI/shadows.

extraInfo: *Technical information is from anecdotal message board remarks by gamers who purchased Fantasy Life, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing - 'Base PS5 has the same 2 modes that also both run at 4K. However, base PS5 standard mode is usually around 75-80fps.'

name: Faraway Train
extraInfo: *Technical information is from anecdotal message board remarks by gamers who purchased Faraway Train, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing - 'There's no 120fps support. There's a PC-style settings menu featuring low, medium, high, and highest presets for draw distance, antialiasing quality, shadow quality, internal render resolution, effects quality, and post processing quality. On Pro, this all defaulted to Highest, whereas certain settings are presumably lower on base PS5.'

name: Farming Simulator 25
extraInfo: Whereas base PS5 has a quality (1600p to 4K at 30fps) and performance 60fps mode, Pro just has a singular mode that runs at a native 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

name: Fatal Frame II: CB Remake
pageTitle: Fatal Frame II: Crimson Butterfly Remake
extraInfo: According to Koei's website, both base PS5 and Pro have 1 mode that outputs at 4K after upscaling, have a max framerate of 30fps, and use the 'standard' quality of character models. However, the notes section mentions the use of dynamic resolution scaling and potential frame drops during gameplay (cutscenes are capped at 30fps too). To presumably get the Pro enhanced badge then (as both consoles have the same description), Pro will utilize a higher DRS before upscaling to 4K - resulting in a sharper image than on base PS5 in the same scene. Pro's extra horsepower should also result in a more stable 30fps. Although as a remake of a PS2 game, there really should be a 60fps mode. Regardless, we'll see how close the website's platform descriptions match the final game when it launches in March 2026.

name: FBC: Firebreak
extraInfo: Unlike Alan Wake 2, which offered a graphics, balanced and performance mode, FBC only has one mode that's 4K at a mostly locked 60fps with no RT. The only toggle on Pro is whether you want to use PSSR or FSR2 as your upscaler to 4K. This isn't an option on base PS5 (which uses FSR2 to upscale to 1440p) as it can't use PSSR.

name: Final Fantasy VII Rebirth

modes.name: versatility
modes.description: 1224p-1440 DRS to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1880p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode(s), with a sharp or smooth variation. 1152p-1440p DRS at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Pro's new versatility mode runs at 1224p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a very stable 60fps. All legacy base PS5 modes are present and its 30fps graphics mode can have a much higher internal resolution. However Pro's PSSR implementation, though a bit noisier/unstable, still creates a sharper image (especially distant detail) than even graphics mode, with better SSR and less ghosting/artifacting, and at 60fps. Considering versatility mode has both the clearest image and highest/most stable framerate (its 60fps is more stable than the either legacy performance mode), all other modes are redundant unless you really can't stand any image stability.

name: Fortnite
rtTypes: Hardware-based ray traced reflections, shadows and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1350p to 4K TSR at a near locked 60fps with hardware-based RT reflections, shadows & global illumination.

modes.name: 120fps performance
modes.description: 1080p to 4K TSR at a basically locked 120fps, but with no RT.

extraInfo: Pro's performance mode looks practically identical to base PS5's performance mode. Base PS5's fidelity mode only uses software-based RT, meaning Pro has better RT implementation due to being hardware-based (less breakup/shimmering/pop-in, more detailed/stable assets, character models in reflections, more accurate indirect lighting).

name: Forza Horizon 5

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps. RT reflections on player car in races and free roam gameplay.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps. Same graphical settings as quality mode, but with no RT reflections.

extraInfo: Graphics in Pro's performance mode are equivalent to base PS5's quality mode, but at a locked 60fps instead of 30fps. Base PS5's performance mode is a big step down from all others. It has far less foliage onscreen, more pop-in, and can render under 4K (DRS hovers around 1728p-1872p when it drops) for a few seconds. RT on Pro is nice, but only affects certain assets (only player car, not other racers etc) and is hard to notice in general gameplay. Cutscenes are 30fps regardless of mode or console.

name: Frostpunk 2

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TSR at 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Upscaled 4K PSSR/TSR at 40fps. Requires a 120 Hz display.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 4K PSSR/TSR at 60fps. Lower internal resolution (presumably) than balanced mode to go from 40fps to 60fps.

extraInfo: Despite Frostpunk 2 not being marked as Pro Enhanced on the PSN store, it absolutely is by the mere fact that it offers PSSR as an upscaler. Based off other UE5 games that also give the choice between PSSR and TSR (like Hellblade 2, Hell Is Us etc), it's likely that TSR upscales a more stable image, but the difference is only slight and neither provide a FPS advantage. Base PS5 has the same modes but at (presumably) worse internal resolutions, though pixel counts aren't currently available.

name: Full Metal Schoolgirl
extraInfo: While Pro can reach up to 120fps, base PS5 is capped at 60fps. In general combat, Pro's framerate is usually around 75-95fps, with rare dips to around 65fps and can still hit 120fps relatively often. Both Pro and base PS5 also render at 4K and neither natively support HDR.

name: Gears Of War: Reloaded

modes.name: 60 Hz
modes.description: 1620p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: 120 Hz
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at 90-120fps (usually around 100fps).

extraInfo: Pro has improved shadows/reflections (less noisy etc) over base PS5. The internal resolution for base PS5's 60 HZ mode is only 1440p compared to Pro's 1620p, and its 120 HZ mode internally renders at 1080p compared to Pro's 1440p. While both consoles then upscale to 4K, Pro uses PSSR, which results in sharper foliage/textures compared to base PS5's FSR3. Additionally, while both consoles maintain a locked 60fps in their 60 Hz modes, base PS5 is usually around 20fps lower than Pro in their 120 HZ modes and drops to 70fps. Between the same 1440p internal resolution and the superior PSSR upscale, Pro's 120 HZ mode is actually sharper than base PS5's 60 HZ mode, with better graphical settings, at nearly 2x the framerate.

name: Ghost Of Ytei

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps without RT. Up to 40fps with VRR/uncapped.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Higher DRS than performance mode, but still upscaled to 4K PSSR and now at a locked 40fps without RT. Up to 60fps with VRR/uncapped.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p-1800p DRS to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps without RT. Averages 75-95fps in general gameplay and 71fps in large combat scenarios with VRR/uncapped.

modes.name: ray tracing
modes.description: 1728p-1800p DRS to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps with RT. Up to 40fps with VRR/uncapped.

modes.name: ray tracing balanced
modes.description: Higher DRS than RT Pro mode, but still upscaled to 4K PSSR and now at a locked 40fps with RT. Averages 44fps in large combat scenarios but averages mid 50s in general gameplay and up to 60fps with VRR/uncapped.

modes.name: ray tracing pro
modes.description: 1080p-1656p DRS (around 1440p average) to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps with RT. Averages 70-90fps in general gameplay and 68fps in large combat scenarios with VRR/uncapped. Exclusive to Pro.

extraInfo: The first 5 modes are also on base PS5, but Pro has a higher internal resolution (base PS5 quality mode is as low as 1800p, 1080p-1440p DRS in performance mode and 1440p in ray tracing mode etc). Base PS5 is also only capable of RTGI at up to 60fps with VRR unlocked. RTGI can significantly enhance image quality (especially scenes with lots of sunlight) with more realistic lighting and shadows that adds nuance/depth. Despite the 1080p-1656p internal resolution in RT Pro mode, its excellent PSSR implementation results in an image as sharp as quality mode's native 4K. PSSR also trades blows in image quality - some assets are a little noisier, but others are more stable/have less ghosting with PSSR. With VRR, Pro averages slightly higher framerates than the equivalent mode on base PS5 (71fps vs 64fps avg in performance mode etc). However, uncapping the framerate results in the lower bounds of the mode's DRS being hit more often. Finally, cutscenes are 30fps regardless of mode/console.

name: Goals

modes.name: Favor Quality
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps with improved graphical settings.

modes.name: Favor Performance
modes.description: 1440p+ (likely) to 4K at a basically locked 120fps.

extraInfo: *All tech info is based off the playtest and is subject to change for the 1.0 launch later in 2026. While favor performance mode has some graphical effects either disabled or simplified, any differences are virtually indistinguishable during gameplay. As both modes also lock to their framerate target 99% of the time, 120fps is the right choice (unless you can't stand very slight reductions in areas like resolution, which is still 4K-like). Finally, base PS5 also has the same modes that mostly lock to the same target framerates. However as a beta, it's likely that Pro enhancements aren't in Goals yet as base PS5 modes look identical to their Pro equivalent. The only consistent difference was base PS5 running at 58fps when aiming corner kicks compared to 60fps on Pro - a difference that's almost certainly due to Pro's extra horsepower.

name: God Of War: Ragnark
rtTypes: Very light ray traced reflections for scene-aligned cube maps

modes.name: PS5 pro enhanced
modes.description: Graphical settings of favor quality mode (RT, better shadows/ambient occlusion/textures & longer draw distance than HFR mode), but runs at 60fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Unlocks framerate for up to 120fps (often around 70-105fps depending on upscaler) on VRR displays.

modes.name: Favor Quality
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode capped at 30fps. Now redundant.

modes.name: Favor Performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode capped at 60fps. Now redundant.

extraInfo: Pro can toggle between TAA and PSSR for upscaling. PSSR is sharper and clearer (especially distant assets) with less fizzle in motion, but less stable with around 10-20fps fewer in HFR mode. Both upscalers use 1440p as the base resolution but PS5 Pro Enhanced mode can regularly have an internal resolution of around 1800p. No need to bother with the legacy base PS5 modes as there are no advantages to do so.

name: Gran Turismo 7

modes.name: 8K 60 Hz
modes.description: 4K to 8K PSSR at a locked 60fps, but with no RT. Requires PSSR to upscale.

modes.name: prioritize ray-tracing/resolution
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Unlike base PS5, RT reflections are now available during gameplay. Its excellent implementation is far superior to the cube maps used when RT is disabled. Both TAA and PSSR are available for upscaling and both support RT except for cockpit mode, which is only PSSR. PSSR still looks great, but can can produce additional shimmer/noise in thin objects and artifacting on a few cars compared to TAA. All framerates are locked 99% of the time in gameplay, but replays can drop the framerate more often. Finally, Pro significantly improves motion clarity and image quality in its optional PSVR2 mode.

name: Grand Theft Auto 6
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination and reflections
extraInfo: *GTA 6 isn't confirmed to be Pro enhanced yet, but considering its pedigree, it's the one game worth speculating. All info is from DF's analysis of real-time base PS5 gameplay, making it a good baseline of what to expect on Pro. GTA 6's resolution was 1440p. There's diffuse RTGI for direct/indirect lighting and it's more stable compared to software UE5 Lumen that's popular on consoles. There's RT reflections that includes dynamic objects like people, even on rough/opaque surfaces (water etc), but SSR is still sometimes used in combination. RT reflections on transparent surfaces (glass) is top-tier. There's no RT shadows, but still looks great with accurate diffuse. The trailer's most impressive aspect is the accurate/natural hair rendering, regardless of hairstyle and even body hair. Finally, even on Pro, a 60fps mode is unlikely, but 40fps could be possible - especially with the delay to November 2026 which gives the Rockstar time to implement FSR4 and/or PSSR2.

name: Hell Is Us

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p common DRS to 4K PSSR/TSR at a basically locked 30fps. Improved LODs, draw distance, shadows, lighting, reflections, textures over performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p common DRS to 4K PSSR/TSR at a basically locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Both of base PS5's modes also have a 1080p common internal resolution before upscaling to 4K. The biggest differences are in graphical settings - particularly level of detail, where quality mode on both consoles transform the image due to a significant increase in assets like foliage. Pro is also more stable than base PS5 in both modes, but all modes only dip 1-2fps. It just happens less often on Pro. Pro can also use TSR and PSSR for upscaling, but neither provide a significant advantage in image quality or framerate. As a UE5 game, TSR is likely the safer option in the long-run though.

name: Hellblade 1
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: enrich visuals
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps with RT reflections and ambient occlusion.

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a basically locked 120fps with RT reflections.

extraInfo: Hellblade came to Series X in 2021 and had 3 modes - 4K/30fps with RT reflections (enrich visuals), 4K/60fps with no RT (resolution), and 1080p/120fps with no RT (performance). This is essentially what came to base PS5, meaning Pro is a big improvement in all modes - especially enrich visuals mode with its 2x framerate and introduction of RTAO. Pro can also use PSSR except in performance mode, which can improve some LOD quality, but the image is otherwise very similar.

name: Hellblade 2: Senua's Saga
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-1700p DRS (1696p avg) to 4K PSSR/TSR (inc black bars) at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 720p-1200p DRS (1166p avg) to 4K PSSR/TSR (inc black bars) at a locked 60fps. Similar graphical fidelity as base PS5 quality mode.

extraInfo: Base PS5 quality/performance modes average 1432p/989p and max out at 1600p/1080p - all of which are lower than Pro's equivalent mode. Pro also utilizes VRS and upscales to 4K in both modes, whereas base PS5 performance mode targets 1440p, then spatially upscales to 4K. This all creates a sharper image on Pro regardless of mode, especially rock/foliage/distant terrain. And with a more stable 60fps (though base PS5 is still good). PSSR is slightly noisier/blurrier than TSR in stills, but clearer in motion. However, any differences between upscalers are minimal due to heavy post-processing (chromatic aberration/film grain etc). Base PS5 performance mode has worse shadows, fog, and Lumen lighting/GI over its quality mode, but these are improved (sometimes back to quality mode settings) for Pro performance mode.

name: Helldivers 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at an improperly paced, but stable 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a mostly stable 60fps (drops to 50s with explosions etc).

extraInfo: Pro sees resolution increases in both modes as on base PS5, quality mode is 1728p and performance is 1080p. However, both consoles render a relatively unstable image due to mediocre TAA, regardless of mode. There's therefore a larger gap between performance modes, with less shimmering/clearer text on Pro. Pro's 60fps is more stable than base PS5, with only the hardest difficulties causing 5-10fps drops (still within VRR). Both quality modes are improperly paced, but Pro is more stable.

name: Hitman Trilogy
extraInfo: Pro is a locked 60fps at 4K native, compared to the 1800p mostly stable 60fps on base PS5. Essentially, putting Pro on par with the Series X version.

name: Highway Drifter: Hajwala
extraInfo: While Highway Drifter has the Pro Enhanced badge on the PSN Store, it's unclear what enhancements, if any, are actually present. Both base PS5 and Pro run at a locked 60fps. However, both consoles share image quality issues, including extreme pop-in, stair-stepped occlusion around the car on wet roads, and shimmering/instability on certain assets. Both also use SSR for reflections and seem to render at the same resolution, as they exhibit an identical number of stair-stepped edges in menus - something easy to verify due to no anti-aliasing. If there are Pro enhancements, they're minimal at best and base PS5 is easily capable of delivering the same experience.

name: Hogwarts Legacy

modes.name: fidelity ray-tracing
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 30fps with RT reflections and shadows.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1728p to 4K PSSR at locked 30fps without RT.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Only for 120 Hz screens. 4K PSSR at nearly locked 40fps without RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at nearly locked 60fps without RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: Only for 120 Hz/VRR screens. Can drop to 1080p as base resolution and no framerate cap. Usually around 80fps without RT.

extraInfo: You can remove the framerate cap in the fidelity and balanced modes, increasing the framerate by 5-10fps. RT shadows are better quality than base PS5, but less accurate on some moving objects. RT reflections have twice the resolution on Pro compared to base PS5. It also applies to bodies of water unlike base PS5 which uses SSR, though can look noisy due to PSSR. Pro performance modes have same graphical settings as the other Pro modes outside of RT. Base PS5 uses FSR 1 to upscale, which looks sharper, but more aliased than PSSR.

name: Hole Digging Master
extraInfo: Both the Pro and base PS5 version are the same for all intents and purposes (the framerate is a locked 60fps on both for example). At best, Pro has a negligible increase in resolution that you'd find hard to notice even when looking at both versions side by side. Non-Pro enhanced games like Metaphor: ReFantazio showcase more significant improvements simply due to Pro's increased horsepower.

name: Horizon 1 Zero Dawn

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: 1584p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 also has DRS that hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode, which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance mode even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon Forbidden West) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Horizon 2 Forbidden West

modes.name: favor resolution pro
modes.description: 1584p-4K native DRS at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced pro
modes.description: Looks almost identical to favor performance pro mode, but is capped at 40fps.

modes.name: favor performance pro
modes.description: 1440p-1584p DRS to 4K at a locked 60fps, or around 65fps with VRR. Very slightly more blurry than favor resolution pro mode (particularly SSR) due to lower base resolution before upscaling, but looks less aliased in motion.

extraInfo: All 3 modes have improved shadows, depth-of-field, skin/hair shaders, clouds, god rays etc compared to base PS5, and these improvements are even more noticeable in motion. Base PS5 also has DRS that hits max 1800p checkerboarding in performance mode, which looks far blurrier (especially foliage and SSR in bodies of water) and more aliased/unstable than Pro performance mode. Pro performance mode even beats base PS5 resolution mode except for slightly blurrier SSR. Digital Foundry thinks it's the best looking console game (along with Horizon Zero Dawn) ever! Equivalent to a high-end PC game and even beats DLSS in places like SSR.

name: Hunt: Showdown 1896
extraInfo: According to Crytek, Pro has 'increased graphical settings' compared to base PS5 and Pro's 60fps is more stable. PSSR also creates a sharper image than the 1260p to 4K FSR2 on base PS5. However, Pro's PSSR implementation results in a lot more shimmering/flickering than FSR2. To the point that many feel Pro's image looks worse despite the sharper render.

name: Hunting Simulator 3
extraInfo: Nacon Studio Ghent have confirmed to me that they have nothing to share about the technical specifications of Hunting Simulator 3 at this time. This is understandable as HS3 doesn't even have a release window yet, let alone a firm date.

name: Hypercharge: Unboxed
extraInfo: Digital Cybercherries has confirmed that a PS5 Pro patch is in development, though no timeline or specific enhancements have been announced. Given that Hypercharge already runs at native 4K and is primarily a multiplayer-focused title, the most logical upgrade would be the addition of a 120fps mode. Ray tracing reflections could also meaningfully enhance the game's visuals, especially in the campaign, thanks to its cartoon/toy-like aesthetic. However, 120fps support would likely remain the priority as most players engage with the game through PvP.

name: Indiana Jones: GC
pageTitle: Indiana Jones And The Great Circle
extraInfo: Pro's dynamic resolution scale ranges from 1440p to native 4K, which it regularly hits. Base PS5's DRS only renders up to 1800p and dips as low as 1200p. Both consoles have a very stable 60fps framerate, but Pro hits 60fps slightly more often. Even with its slightly improved RTGI and ambient occlusion/shadows implementation. There's no option to unlock the framerate, even though Pro looks like it has the headroom for a noticeable increase past 60fps. Cutscenes are locked to 60fps everywhere (even PC).

name: Into Black
extraInfo: Pro supports 120 Hz natively whereas base PS5 only supports a 90 Hz refresh rate. Both consoles support remastered environments (enhanced water, flora, fauna, geometry, textures etc) and dynamic real-time shadows.

name: Isonzo
extraInfo: Pro uses PSSR to upscale to 4K, whereas base PS5 uses FSR 2.2 to upscale to 1800p. While both consoles also use DRS, Pro internally renders between 756p-1440p, whereas base PS5 is between 630p-1200p. Between the higher internal DRS and output resolution, Pro looks noticeably sharper. Pro also runs in High CPU Frequency mode for improved performance (a more stable framerate that targets 60fps, but can go up to 120fps with HFR/VRR).

name: Jurassic World Evolution 3
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination and sun shadows
extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro run at 30fps and have RTGI. However, only Pro has RT sun shadows. This provides accurate penumbra for shadows, making subtle details more noticeable due to the increased contrast. RT sun shadows also provides greater realism, with shadows cast by foliage/dinosaurs appearing softer the further the shadow is from them. Pro's PSSR upscaling from a high internal resolution should also provide sharper assets like foliage, trees and water reflections compared to base PS5.

name: Karma: The Dark World
extraInfo: The developers claim Pro is native 4K, but also using PSSR in order to get a 'rock solid' 60fps. Pro also has enhanced texture streaming and volumetric effects, higher quality texture filtering, improved distance rendering, and better temporal stability compared to base PS5.

name: Kayak VR: Mirage
extraInfo: Pro has 8K textures compared to 4K on base PS5. Pro also has improved post-processing, effects, LOD distance and anti-aliasing. Both consoles have dynamic resolution scaling, but Pro only hits a low of 90% of 4K, whereas base PS5 can only render between 60%-90% of 4K.

name: Killing Floor 3
extraInfo: While Pro utilizes UE5's TSR to target an upscaled 1800p, base PS5 only targets 1440p. These outputs are however dynamic, but at least Pro targets a noticeably higher ceiling. The framerate does dip below 60fps on both Pro and base PS5, but should stay within the VRR window for most of the instances it does dip.

name: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2
extraInfo: Pro is 1296p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps, or around 70fps (highs of 90s) with VRR. Base PS5 is only 1080p to 1440p FSR at 60fps, though 1440p to 4K FSR at 30fps. Even though Pro can have a lower internal resolution than base PS5 fidelity mode before upscaling, PSSR still produces the clearest (albeit a little noisier) image. Pro also has the same improved tree/shadow LODs, ambient occlusion and object quality of base PS5 fidelity mode, but at 60+fps.

name: Kinki Spiritual Affairs B
extraInfo: *Technical information is from anecdotal message board remarks by gamers who purchased KSAB, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing - 'While you can manually change the resolution to 1080p/1440p/4K and framerate to 30fps/60fps, KSAB comes with recommended settings. This is 1440p/60fps on Pro and 1080p/60fps on base PS5. Considering the graphics of KSAB, 4K at a very stable 60fps should still be possible on Pro (at least with a VRR screen).'

name: Lies Of P

modes.name: quality-centered
modes.description: 4K at 30fps, or 40fps+ if HFR (VRR) is activated. Higher quality shadows, textures, SSR and volumetric fog than performance-centered mode.

modes.name: performance-centered
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps. HFR is disabled in this mode.

extraInfo: Pro performance-centered mode is a native 4K, whereas base PS5 performance-centered mode has DRS that internally renders between 1512p-1800p, before upscaling to 4K. Pro quality-centered mode also has at least a 30% increase in FPS (with VRR enabled) compared to base PS5 quality-centered mode's 30fps.

name: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
pageTitle: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii
extraInfo: While both Pro and base PS5 run at 60fps, Pro's framerate is basically locked at 60fps whereas base PS5 can dip below more often. Base PS5's lower 1080p internal resolution (compared to Pro's 1440p) also results in noticeably more fizzle in assets like hair.

name: Little Nightmares III

modes.name: beauty
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS (likely) to 4K at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p (likely) to 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Graphical settings (shadows/lighting etc) are the same in both modes. While performance mode can have a slightly lower internal resolution before upscaling to 4K, the game's heavy post-processing results in there being very little difference in image quality/sharpness between the 2 modes. By picking beauty mode, you're essentially just halving your framerate for no graphical benefit - unless you can't stand single frame drops on rare occasion. The same is true for base PS5, which also has the same modes and no significant downgrade in resolution compared to the equivalent mode on Pro.

name: Lonely Hospital
extraInfo: The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the framerate. While Pro runs at a basically locked 60fps, base PS5 hovers in the low 50s and regularly dips below the 48fps VRR window. Both consoles output a 4K-like image, however both exhibit significant noise/instability in reflections which suggests a low internal resolution. Pro's internal resolution is likely slightly higher as its noise is a bit more stable, but any resolution differences are minimal - the framerate stability is the true game changer.

name: Lords Of The Fallen

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps with Lumen GI.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K via a custom version of UE5's upscaling at 60fps plus Lumen.

extraInfo: Hexworks states that Pro has a 40% increase in pixels compared to base PS5, resulting in sharper distant details and more refined textures on characters/environments. In practice, this increase can be even larger as base PS5 performance mode is between 648p-1152p DRS and quality mode is 1296p-1620p DRS.
