Pro also hits its target framerate more often than base PS5 in both modes and is equivalent to the highest PC graphical settings.

name: Lords Of The Fallen II

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps with Lumen GI.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K via a custom version of UE5's upscaling at 60fps plus Lumen.

extraInfo: *LOTF II isn't out yet, but the following information from last year's LOTF Pro patch provides a good baseline of what to expect - 'Hexworks states that Pro has a 40% increase in pixels compared to base PS5, resulting in sharper distant details and more refined textures on characters/environments. In practice, this increase can be even larger as base PS5 performance mode is between 648p-1152p DRS and quality mode is 1296p-1620p DRS. Pro also hits its target framerate more often than base PS5 in both modes and is equivalent to the highest PC graphical settings.'

name: Lost Soul Aside
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and global illumination

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 1080p-1662p to 4K at a very stable 30fps with RT.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1080p-1398p to 4K at a stable 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Base PS5 quality mode also has DRS between 1080p-1662p, but its performance mode is 635p-1189p. With an internal resolution as low as 635p before upscaling to 4K, base PS5 is noticeably blurrier, with more instability/fizzle in shadows/reflections/distant assets compared to Pro Performance mode, which is still very sharp/stable. Pro also has a more stable framerate in both of its modes, although there's still some minor drops (within VRR). Pro also has better RT reflections/shadows/GI, higher texture quality, more detailed particle effects and faster loading compared to base PS5.

name: Madden NFL 25
extraInfo: Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5 resolution mode (especially grass, which is now 3D during gameplay in more zoomed in cameras), but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more shimmery/unstable. All cutscenes/instant replays are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps.

name: Madden NFL 26
extraInfo: *Madden 26 is the first current-gen only entry. However, its Pro enhancements mirrors Madden 25 (all tech info on the page). Madden 26 still provides a visual upgrade over Madden 25 though due to this year's focus on stadium presentation/authenticity and extreme weather visuals. It's just that these improvements are also on base PS5 - 'Removes the resolution, performance and visual quality modes seen in base PS5 for just one Pro mode. PSSR renders a sharper image than even base PS5 resolution mode (especially grass, which is now 3D during gameplay in more zoomed in cameras), but it causes certain assets like crowd handrails to be more shimmery/unstable. All cutscenes/instant replays are now also 60fps like in base PS5 performance mode and gameplay is a locked 60fps.'

name: Mafia: The Old Country
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1189p-1552p DRS to 4K TSR at a locked 30fps, or 40-60fps with Vsync off.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1008p-1189p DRS to 4K TSR at a basically locked 60fps. Reduced vegetation, shadows, draw distance, lighting, resolution, terrain, and reflections quality.

extraInfo: While Pro's performance mode only dips to 1008p, base PS5 performance mode falls to 720p for much of the time. In quality mode, base PS5's 831p-960p DRS is below even Pro's lowest 1189p DRS bounds. Furthermore, base PS5 only upscales to 1440p in both modes, whereas Pro upscales to 4K. Pro also applies fewer cuts to its graphical settings (shadows/lighting etc) in its performance mode (Lumen reflections are even better than base PS5 quality mode), and all of Pro quality mode's graphical settings are higher than base PS5 quality mode. Base PS5 quality mode has a higher average framerate that primarily stays within the VRR window though, whereas Pro's doesn't, and both maintain a solid 60fps in their performance modes with no option to go higher.

name: Mandragora: WOTWT
pageTitle: Mandragora: Whispers of the Witch Tree

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 4K native at a stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p native that targets 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has one mode that runs at 1800p/60fps. While this is just slightly worse than Pro's 4K/60fps quality mode, it means that Pro has an exclusive 120fps mode for gamers who prefer to maximize the framerate.

name: Marathon
extraInfo: Marathon's PlayStation Store object confirms that Pro will internally render at native 5K, then use PSSR to downscale to 4K. Considering the very high internal resolution, a 120fps mode should be possible (at the cost of a much softer image like 1440p) although nothing is confirmed. At the very least, the internal 5K resolution should negate any potential PSSR rendering problems seen in games that use sub-1080p internal resolutions and/or UE5's Lumen for various forms of RT (Silent Hill 2 etc).

name: Marvel Rivals
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen global illumination and reflections

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, with Lumen Reflections & GI.

modes.name: HFR
modes.description: 1440p at a nearly locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has Lumen GI in its 60fps quality mode, whereas Pro also has Lumen Reflections. Pro's PSSR implementation renders a sharper image than possible on base PS5, but is also a bit noisier/unstable. Pro also not only hits 120fps in its HFR mode much more often than base PS5, which regularly dips to around 110fps, but does so at a higher resolution too.

name: MechWarrior 5: Clans
extraInfo: The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the framerate (at least in the game's early missions as later ones weren't tested). Base PS5 can hit 60fps, but can also hover in the mid 50s and regularly dips below the 48fps VRR window during combat. Pro is a much more stable 60fps and is regularly 4-5fps more in combat, with only rare/quick dips below VRR. Pro's internal resolution is also slightly higher than base PS5, but neither console output a convincing 4K image. For example, they both exhibit soup-like textures in some foliage, shimmering on assets like railings, and image breakup in water effects/shadows etc. The shimmering/image breakup is just less prevalent on Pro, making the framerate stability the real game changer.

name: Metaball
extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro run at a locked 60fps. However, base PS5's more 1080p-like resolution leads to a blurrier image, with more noticeable aliasing on characters and stadium edges, as well as more instability in reflections. Pro could potentially dip to around 1440p as some jaggies from aliasing are present, but it's never as bad as what you even immediately see on Metaball's main menu on base PS5.

name: Metal Eden

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a stable 50-60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lower DRS than quality mode, but at a basically locked 60fps.

extraInfo: While internal resolutions are unknown, quality mode is much higher as it resolves a far more convincing 4K-like output after upscaling. This image quality increase is best seen in areas like lighting, reflections, and various wall textures that are sharper with less image stability/breakup. However, quality mode struggles to maintain 60fps for extended periods, but stays above 48fps so works well with VRR screens. Finally, base PS5 also has the same modes with similar resolution differences, but its quality mode is capped at 30fps (performance still at 60fps). Fortunately, both base PS5 modes are able to basically lock to their target framerates.

name: Metal Gear Solid Delta: SE
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 756p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a stable 50-60fps in stealth (see extra info).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 720p-1260p DRS to 4K PSSR with worse AO and Lumen GI than quality mode, but at a basically locked 60fps in stealth. Patch 1.21 added this mode.

extraInfo: Pro's modes have the improved object LODs/shadows/GI in base PS5's unevenly paced 30fps quality mode (to different extents), while targeting 60fps. Patch 1.21 ensures a somewhat stable framerate within the VRR window providing you maintain stealth (dips to as low as 35fps in gunfights due to enemy AI/CPU limits). In stills, Pro is blurrier than even base PS5 performance mode (720p-1080p DRS to 4K FSR) due to low DRS/PSSR, let alone base PS5 quality mode's 1080p-1584p DRS. However, PSSR has less GI flickering, less artifacting in hair/foliage, reduced ghosting/breakup and sharper motion clarity, making it the better upscaler overall. Both Pro modes also have a more stable framerate than base PS5 performance mode, though cutscenes are an unstable 60fps everywhere.

name: Microsoft Flight Sim 2024
extraInfo: Base PS5 and Pro upscale to 4K, but base PS5's internal resolution is 1440p compared to Pro's sharper 1800p. However, other image metrics are harder to compare due to the compulsory use of the Cloud to stream in the world (Xbox can download Earth to SSD). For example, particularly bad pop in could be caused by the game itself or the Cloud's current bandwidth. The same flight on the same PS5 can therefore render different image quality, although Pro generally has less pop in and increased draw distances. Both consoles also default to a 30fps cap, but can be unlocked with VRR. However, even with the PC-like menu of 10+ graphical settings (character quality, fauna density etc) set to their lowest, the framerate rarely reaches 60fps, can even dip to 25fps-27fps when flying low in cities, and is generally between 30-40fps (with Pro averaging 3-4fps higher). Finally, there's no RT shadows seen in PC's cockpit mode, which DF speculated could be a Pro-exclusive enhancement.

name: Midnight Murder Club
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 run at 4K. Instead, Pro surpasses base PS5 by its ability to maintain a locked 60fps, regardless of what VFX Quality setting is chosen. There is very low, low, medium, high and best, and it's at these higher options where base PS5 can dip below 60fps. Especially if the FOV is also on a wider setting (although still within VRR window). Pro will however remain a locked 60fps even if both VFX Quality and FOV are maxed out.

name: Mind Labyrinth VR Dreams
extraInfo: Technical information outside of framerate is based off My World's other PSVR2 title, Oniriam, which had more than a 20% increase in resolution and a more stable framerate on Pro. This provides a good baseline of expectations as My World hasn't commented on MLVD's Pro support. However, anecdotal message board remarks claim MLVD has no signs of reprojection, unlike Oniriam which was definitively 60 Hz to 120 Hz reprojection. This is potentially due to MLVD being a remake of a smaller-scoped PSVR1 title and is therefore not necessarily going for the top of the range graphics that would need to use reprojection to achieve this.

name: MindsEye
extraInfo: MindsEye is one of very few Pro games that lacks a 60fps mode. However, it also struggles to maintain a stable, properly paced 30fps - regularly dipping into the low 20s in various open-world and combat scenarios, with lots of screen tearing (base PS5 performs even worse as it drops to under 20fps). Pro also has slightly improved textures, terrain detail and shadows over base PS5, but its upscaled 4K output still looks very blurry when at its lowest internal resolution. Image stability is however still much better on Pro compared to base PS5, which can internally render below 720p. At the very least, cutscene quality on both consoles looks much better than gameplay.

name: Monster E Supercross 25
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off MotoGP 25 as there's no public information about MES 25's Pro enhancements. However, as both games are by Milestone, use Unreal Engine 5, and have a similar aesthetic/scope, MotoGP provides a good baseline of what to expect from MES - 'During gameplay, Pro runs runs between 80-120fps regardless of track/weather effects, but is usually between 90-110fps. The actual rider/track are 4K-like, but background assets such as trees/railings/stands look soft and do shimmer. This suggest a relatively low internal resolution before outputting to 4K, which makes sense considering the high framerate target. Base PS5 looks slightly blurrier and only runs between 65-80fps, with rare ceilings of 95fps, but at least doesn't fall below 60fps.'

name: Monster Hunter Wilds

modes.name: prioritize resolution
modes.description: 1728p-1944p DRS to 4K PSSR with RT reflections. Nearly locked 30fps, or up to 45fps with VRR.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1404p to 4K PSSR with very slightly worse RT than prioritize resolution mode. Nearly locked 40fps, or low 40s in VRR.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR with RT disabled. Nearly locked 60fps, or up to 80fps with VRR. Worse GI, lighting and LODs than other modes.

extraInfo: RT reflections look significantly better than SSR due to no occlusion issues. Pro's PSSR looks much better than base PS5's FSR1 as the image (though slightly softer) has a lot less aliasing/breakup and more temporal stability. This contrast is widened as internal resolution lowers to as low as 720p on base PS5. Pro prioritize framerate mode also hits 60fps more often than the base PS5 version. There's no LFC, so VRR isn't recommended in resolution/balanced modes that rarely reach above 60fps anyways.

name: Mortal Kombat 1
extraInfo: The only big difference between Pro and base PS5 is how reflections are rendered. Pro uses RT, whereas base PS5 uses less accurate SSR (screen space reflections). Pro still has dynamic resolution scaling that can go as low as 1800p, but renders at native 4K more often than base PS5. Finally, both consoles run at a basically locked 60fps.

name: Motel Business Simulator
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off Hole Digging Master as there's no public information about Motel Business Simulator's Pro enhancements. However, as both games are by Nostra and have a similar aesthetic/scope, HDM provides a good baseline of what to expect from MBS - 'Both the Pro and base PS5 version are the same for all intents and purposes (the framerate is a locked 60fps on both for example). At best, Pro has a negligible increase in resolution that you'd find hard to notice even when looking at both versions side by side. Non-Pro enhanced games like Metaphor: ReFantazio showcase more significant improvements simply due to Pro's increased horsepower.'

name: MotoGP 25
extraInfo: During gameplay, Pro runs runs between 80-120fps regardless of track/weather effects, but is usually between 90-110fps. The actual rider/track are 4K-like, but background assets such as trees/railings/stands look soft and do shimmer. This suggest a relatively low internal resolution before outputting to 4K, which makes sense considering the high framerate target. Base PS5 looks slightly blurrier and only runs between 65-80fps, with rare ceilings of 95fps, but at least doesn't fall below 60fps.

name: My Time At Sandrock

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 has the same modes that target the same resolutions. However, the framerate is less stable (drops to 55fps in base PS5 fidelity mode etc). *All tech information is based off figures taken from various message boards, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing.

name: My First Gran Turismo

modes.name: 8K 60 Hz
modes.description: 4K to 8K PSSR at a locked 60fps, but with no RT. Requires PSSR to upscale.

modes.name: prioritize ray-tracing/resolution
modes.description: 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 60fps with RT reflections.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR/TAA at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: *MFTG is a free, beginner-friendly introduction to the world of GT. Basically, an expanded demo with a limited number of cars/racetracks. However, its tech details remain the same as the premium GT7 product - 'Unlike base PS5, RT reflections are now available during gameplay. Its excellent implementation is far superior to the cube maps used when RT is disabled. Both TAA and PSSR are available for upscaling and both support RT except for cockpit mode, which is only PSSR. PSSR still looks great, but can can produce additional shimmer/noise in thin objects and artifacting on a few cars compared to TAA. All framerates are locked 99% of the time in gameplay, but replays can drop the framerate more often. Finally, Pro significantly improves motion clarity and image quality in its optional PSVR2 mode.'

name: Naraka: Bladepoint

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a stable 60fps. According to 24 Entertainment - 'ideal for users seeking better visual experiences'.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1080p (likely) to 4K PSSR, with either a 60fps or 120fps cap - 'balancing both visual quality and smoothness'.

modes.name: high frames
modes.description: Native 1080p at 60fps, 120fps, 240fps, or 'unlimited' fps (check extra info) - 'for users who need the highest frame rates, ensuring smoother gameplay'.

extraInfo: 60fps at native 4K isn't possible on base PS5. Although high frames mode has toggles for 240fps and unlimited fps, Pro isn't capable of running above 120fps. So in practice, high frames mode has the same 60/120fps cap toggles as balanced mode. It'll just maintain the target framerate more often due to the lower resolution, which it locks to at 60fps.

name: NBA 2K25
extraInfo: The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the addition of RT reflections in The City. Pro also uses PSSR to upscale from 1440p (likely) to 4K. This creates a slightly sharper image compared to base PS5, however PSSR also causes certain assets like handrails in the stands to render a bit more unstable.

name: NBA 2K26
extraInfo: NBA 2K26 has the same Pro enhancements as NBA 2K25. The game does look better than last year due to improved shading/lighting/animations etc, but these are on base PS5 as well - 'The biggest difference between Pro and base PS5 is the addition of RT reflections in The City. Pro also uses PSSR to upscale from 1440p (likely) to 4K. This creates a slightly sharper image compared to base PS5, however PSSR also causes certain assets like handrails in the stands to render a bit more unstable.'

name: NHL 26
extraInfo: Base PS5 internally renders at 1440p before upscaling to 4K, whereas Pro renders at native 4K, which is a 2.25x resolution increase. This results in a sharper image on assets like handrails, goal nets, and jerseys. However, this is the only difference - both run at a locked 60fps with no option for 120fps, for example.

name: Nioh 3
extraInfo: When Nioh 1 & 2 came to PS5, they had a 4K/60fps mode, a 1080p DRS/60fps mode (with higher graphical settings like shadows) and a reduced fidelity 120fps mode. However, Nioh 3's June 2025 demo didn't support 120fps on either Pro or base PS5. Additionally, Nioh 3 was unable to maintain a stable 60fps or a consistent 1080p+ resolution in either its prioritize framerate or prioritize graphics modes on both consoles, though the Pro performed better on average. That said, this was just a demo, so these issues will likely improve by Nioh 3's launch. Unfortunately, given Nioh 3's current-gen only, and now open-world design, hitting 120fps may not be feasible without unacceptable resolution tradeoffs. Hopefully, this also changes with improved optimization before the February 6, 2026 release.

name: Ninja Gaiden 2 Black
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Upscaled 4K TSR at locked 60fps except for some cutscenes (lows of mid 50s).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Upscaled 1080p TSR at somewhat stable 120fps depending on level (lows of 90s). Less detailed shadows/non-Nanite geometry.

extraInfo: There's no actual modes. Instead, you switch between the 2 framerate targets via the FPS limit toggle's 60fps and 120fps values. Both modes use Lumen combined with SSR for reflections and Lumen GI for indirect lighting. Base PS5 has the same 2 modes, however, Pro has a higher base resolution before upscaling and hits its target framerate more often.

name: Ninja Gaiden 4

modes.name: prioritize framerate (pro)
modes.description: 1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps. With VRR, usually 80-100fps in demanding scenes and up to 120fps in open play. Same visual quality settings as prioritize graphics mode.

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p DRS to 4K FSR at a locked, but unevenly paced 30fps, or around 55-65fps with VRR.

modes.name: prioritize framerate
modes.description: 900p-1080p DRS to 4K FSR at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: 120 hz
modes.description: 720p DRS to 1080p FSR at a very stable 120fps (a floor of around 110fps during demanding fights). Much worse graphics settings (see extra info).

extraInfo: Prioritize graphics, framerate and 120 Hz modes are also the modes on base PS5. However, Pro can uncap the framerate (base PS5 can't) and will also reach the higher bounds of the DRS more often. Prioritize framerate Pro takes the visual settings of graphics mode, but runs at 60fps+ instead of 30fps. While both of these mode also internally render at 1440p, base PS5 uses FSR to upscale to 4K whereas Pro uses an excellent implementation of PSSR (both modes looks very 4K-like). The 120 Hz mode has no SSR, missing rain effects, and a far worse draw distance/LODs where many assets like trash bags/rocks don't render at all. It also looks considerably blurrier due to both the lower internal and output resolutions, making it a pointless mode on Pro as its exclusive mode is superior in every way.

name: No Man's Sky

modes.name: 8K resolution
modes.description: 2592-2700p DRS to 8K PSSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a basically locked 60fps.

extraInfo: While base PS5 has a singular mode that also runs at 4K/60fps, both Pro modes have improved lighting, ultra quality reflections and higher quality ambient occlusion. These improvements are also seen in the PSVR2 version. PSSR implementation works very well due to the high base resolution in both modes.

name: Of Lies And Rain

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 60 Hz to 120 Hz reprojection at 1.5x base resolution and 2.5x dynamic foveated rendering.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 120 Hz with no reprojection at 1.0x base resolution and 1.8x dynamic foveated rendering.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode and base PS5 performance/quality modes are at 1.0x base resolution. Whereas Pro quality mode is 1.5x (actual base resolution figure is unknown, but this is still a significant 50% increase). Pro performance mode is also 120 Hz native, whereas base PS5 performance mode is only 90 Hz. All other settings are the same in the equivalent base PS5 mode.

name: Off The Grid

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 65fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p FSR3/TSR/PSSR at usually around 85fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Pro can choose between FSR3, TSR or PSSR for upscaling. All 3 run at a similar fps (give or take 5-10fps) and can be capped at 30/40/60fps. However, while FSR3 and TSR (a bit more stable than FSR3) render a good image, PSSR results in shimmering/flickering, as well as strobing in assets like foliage. Similar to SW Jedi: Survivor when Pro first launched. Fidelity mode renders a 4K-looking image and is 99% locked above the 48fps VRR window. Performance mode has a roughly 20fps increase and even hits 120fps, but the 1080p-like image is much blurrier regardless of upscaler. Finally, OTG is in early access so this tech analysis is likely to change when 1.0 launches.

name: OneTry
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off Quisisana, which was Domynyo's previous game that had a similar genre/scope and therefore provides a good baseline of expectations until OneTry is tested - 'Pro renders at 4K/60fps. However, there's (seemingly) no aliasing solution implemented, so edges of assets like doors/windows etc are still very jagged. Graphical settings such as lighting and some shadows are improved over Domynyo's previous game (Sanguis Luna). However, the differences in these graphical settings between the base PS5 and Pro version seem minimal.'

name: Onimusha: WOTS
extraInfo: Based on the demo at Gamescom, DF have confirmed that the framerate is a somewhat unstable 60fps (dips to 55fps) and there's no RT. This is surprising as both Resident Evil Requiem and Pragmata (who also use Onimusha's RE engine) had a more stable 60fps in their respective demos, despite also utilizing RT reflections/GI. Hopefully the framerate is improved when the game launches next year, although VRR will clean up these minor dips if not.

name: Oniriam
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 use reprojection, but Pro has more than a 20% increase in resolution and a more stable framerate.

name: Only Up Rush
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 run at a very stable 60fps. Pro has a slightly higher resolution which results in a cleaner/more 4K-like image with less shimmer/instability in assets like railings/billboards/tarp etc.

name: Oppidum
extraInfo: Pro is a native 4K at 60fps. This combines the best of base PS5's performance (1440p/60fps) and quality (4K/30fps) modes.

name: Outbreak: SOHCS
pageTitle: Outbreak: Shades of Horror Chromatic Split
extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro likely have the same internal resolution. However, Pro upscales to 4K via PSSR which results in a far sharper image compared to base PS5. Especially with certain graphical effects like rain, which looks sub-1080p on the base console. Pro also improves texture resolution and other visual effects, although the PSSR implementation does cause strobing/instability on certain RT assets. Finally, Pro's 60fps is far more stable - only dipping on rare occasion to mid 50s, whereas base PS5 is constantly dipping from 60fps and can go as low as 45fps in the opening section.

name: Paladin's Passage

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K PSSR at 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at 60fps.

extraInfo: According to the game's website, 'advanced shaders' are now on Pro. PSSR is also used to render up to 8K.

name: Party Animals
extraInfo: Base PS5 likely renders at 1440p, whereas Pro renders a more 4K-like image (except for the very blurry developer start up screen). Both consoles also have a very stable 60fps in the majority of modes most will care about (fights/races etc). However, both consoles struggle in The Lab, with the Pro actually faring worse (mid 40s) and can even drop frames in the main menu.

name: Path Of Exile 2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1662p NIS or PSSR 'quality' to 4K with DRS, at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p NIS or PSSR 'balanced' to 4K without DRS, at a relatively stable 120fps.

extraInfo: With 4 upscalers that each have multiple quality options within them, a sharpness slider, different lighting toggles, multiple refresh rate options (including 30/40fps), and even experimental options like dynamic culling, PoE2 easily has the most configurations of a PS5 Pro game. Instead of listing 50+ modes, the 2 above represent what the general PoE2 community recommend depending on your framerate target. Performance mode can dip in heavy fights, but should stay above 60fps most of the time. NIS is sharper and more performant that PSSR, but less stable in motion and can look too sharp. Though PSSR's softness results in a loss of texture detail. If you want to maximize frames, ensure lighting is set to just 'shadows' instead of  'shadows + GI'. Dynamic culling is also not recommended as it can cause severe graphical issues.

name: Pathfinder: WOTR

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 4K at a mostly stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Quality mode can dip below 60fps, but it's not common. It also only dips to the low 50s, which is well within the VRR window. Performance mode is a locked 60fps, but at 1080p, it's noticeably blurrier than quality mode's 4K. Base PS5 only has one mode which renders at 4K, but with a far more unstable 60fps that regularly falls below the VRR window (usually 35-45fps).

name: Phantom Blade Zero
extraInfo: S-Game have confirmed that base PS5 is targeting a 1440p/60fps mode and a 4K/30fps mode, but that performance mode is currently dropping to as low as 40fps. S-Game have also stated that Pro will have enhanced visuals. Based off these 2 remarks, it's unlikely that Pro will support 120fps. AMD have also provided hardware-base RT solutions to S-Game for PS5. This falls in line with the Gamescom demo DF conducted on a high-end PC, which didn't use UE5's Lumen reflections/GI (or Virtual Shadow Maps). Instead, it used traditional RT reflections (only in bodies of water like puddles) and shadows, as well as baked (non-RT) GI. This targeted RT approach should allow Pro to include multiple RT implementations (to a higher quality base PS5 can't reach) with a stable, non-frame generated 60fps. Unlike other UE5 games such as Black Myth: Wukong. This is currently just speculation though and we'll find out more closer to launch.

name: Pipistrello & Cursed Yoyo
extraInfo: *Technical information is from anecdotal message board remarks by gamers who purchased Pipistrello, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing - 'Both base PS5 and Pro run at a locked 60fps and upscale 160p assets in a 4K image. Both consoles also have some cutscenes in a creator-intended 24fps. If there are actually any graphical improvements for Pro, the difference is so minor that it's difficult to tell even when comparing base PS5 and Pro side by side. Especially in gameplay due to the retro art style.'

name: Planet Coaster 2
extraInfo: The only difference between Pro and base PS5 is resolution - Pro runs at native 4K, whereas base PS5 internally runs at 1440p before upscaling to 4K. This results in Pro rendering sharper assets like foliage, trees and water reflections, as well as less image instability on assets like railings. Both consoles still run at a locked 30fps, and Pro's pause menu (the controller outline etc) and loading screen animations still have the approx 1080p looking jaggies.

name: Pragmata
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and global illumination
extraInfo: Based on the demo at Gamescom, DF have confirmed that there's full RT support. DF also confirmed 60fps, and while there were some minor dips (still within VRR window) during cutscenes, these will likely be ironed out for the final release. It's unlikely that there will be an 120fps mode as the very reflective sterile space station aesthetic requires RT reflections to look good. RE engine is also notoriously poor with what would've been the RT fallback in SSR (screen space reflections).

name: PUBG: Battlegrounds
extraInfo: Pro renders at a dynamic 4K, but base PS5 only renders at a fixed 1440p. Both consoles run at a 'stable' 60fps and neither support 120fps - apparently due to wanting to maintain fairness across platforms during cross-play.

name: Pure Pool Pro

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K native at 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at 120fps.

extraInfo: Ripstone's Reddit/Steam account confirmed that the above modes is what Pro will be targeting. This will be Pro's first and (currently) only game to run at native 8K.

name: Puzzle Quest: Immortal

modes.name: 60fps
modes.description: 4K at a locked 60fps.

modes.name: 120fps
modes.description: Upscaled 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro have a 60fps mode than renders at native 4K and a 120fps mode that renders at upscaled 4K. While the internal resolution for Pro's 120fps is slightly higher, in practice, base PS5's 120fps mode still looks very 4K-like when looking at normal distances. You'll only see the most minute of differences when directly comparing 2 modes or staring at an edge of a triangle gem from a inch away. The locked 120fps mode is therefore the way to go regardless of PS5 console.

name: Quantum Error
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, global illumination and shadows (base PS5)
extraInfo: While TeamKill confirmed they're working on a PS5 Pro update as early as October 2024, this has yet to come to fruition as of January 2026 (the above tech info is taken from the base PS5 version). However, in September 2025, TeamKill confirmed a Pro update was still planned. The reason it's taking time is because QE was developed on an old version of UE5 that didn't support Pro because it didn't even exist. As a small studio, the engine update/upgrade is a huge task - much bigger than having it already incorporated during the development of their new game, Code Violet.  Hopefully when CD releases in January 2026, TeamKill will have the bandwidth to make good on their promise of Pro support for Quantum Error.

name: Quisisana
extraInfo: Pro renders at 4K/60fps. However, there's (seemingly) no aliasing solution implemented, so edges of assets like doors/windows etc are still very jagged. Graphical settings such as lighting and some shadows are improved over Domynyo's previous game (Sanguis Luna). However, the differences in these graphical settings between the base PS5 and Pro version seem minimal.

name: Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps/40fps for 60 Hz/120 Hz screens, or nearly 60fps with VRR. Highest quality RT (explained below).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 80-90fps with VRR.

extraInfo: Fidelity Pro is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, but PSSR in general resolves more detail than the FSR upscaling utilized in every base PS5 mode. Especially in motion with less aliasing etc, but PSSR can be noisier in stills. Performance Pro mode has much sharper RT reflections than base PS5 Performance RT mode. Fidelity Pro RT reflections look even less aliased as they're full resolution and its RTAO has more contact shadows - adding depth to assets all over the screen.

name: Ready Or Not

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p-1552p DRS to 4K native at an unevenly paced 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1350p-1440p DRS to 4K at a nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: VOID stated in a pre-launch interview that Ready or Not uses PSSR in the Pro version. However, it's very unlikely that it's currently Pro enhanced. For one, it doesn't have the Pro enhanced confirmation on the PSN store. It also uses similar DRS bounds compared to the same mode on base PS5 (as seen above). The Series X fares even worse, with downgraded  graphical settings/resolution compared to base PS5. Fortunately, VOID have acknowledged these issues and said this will be fixed in a future patch, which hopefully also comes with proper Pro enhancements. At the very least right now, Pro helps Ready or Not maintain its 60fps more often, though it can still dip into the mid 50s. Due to the unevenly paced 30fps, quality mode isn't recommended as it results in a sub-optimal experience on both PS5 consoles.

name: Redacted

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at a locked 60fps with supersampling.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 doesn't have an 8K mode. It also can't run at 120fps when rendering at 4K. You can choose Pro's quality mode on a non-8K screen, but the game makes it clear that the game will be down-sampled to the resolution of your screen and therefore make this choice pointless.

name: Rennsport
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 run at 60fps. However, Pro renders at a native 4K whereas base PS5 renders at upscaled 4K (internal res before upscaled 4K output unknown).

name: Resident Evil 4

modes.name: resolution
modes.description: Native 4K at a locked 60fps with RT/better hair quality. Can also toggle HFR on which then increases the framerate to 70-90fps.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR without RT/better hair quality. 85-105fps usually, but can be a locked 120fps in interiors.

extraInfo: There's a lot of toggles in this game for RT/HFR/better hair quality etc, so the 2 modes above represent the image quality with all the toggles either on or off. Resolution mode holds a much more stable 60fps than same mode on base PS5, which hovers around 45fps.

name: Resident Evil Requiem

modes.name: ray tracing on
modes.description: 4K at 60fps with RT.

modes.name: ray tracing off
modes.description: 4K at up to 120fps (90fps average) with no RT.

extraInfo: All tech information is based off a Capcom interview prior to launch. Regarding resolution, the interview states '4K output'. It will be interesting to see if this means PSSR is used for possible upscaling as both RE4 and RE8 used it. Regarding RT, RE4 used ray traced reflections while RE8 also used it for global illumination and ambient occlusion. The interview merely mentions 'full ray tracing', so it will be interesting to see exactly what implementations this means when Requiem launches in late Feb.

name: Resident Evil Village
rtTypes: Ray traced global illumination, ambient occlusion and reflections

modes.name: ray tracing
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps with RT.

modes.name: high frame rate
modes.description: 864p to 4K PSSR at a locked 120fps with no RT.

extraInfo: You can actually toggle both RT and HFR on, with the framerate then ranging from from 65fps-90fps. 120fps is not on base PS5, which uses 4K checkerboard rendering (1920x2160) and even then, still can't hold a stable 60fps with RT enabled. PSSR is less sharp compared to base PS5's CBR, but also less noisy, with less artifacting on moving objects like tree branches.

name: Resist
extraInfo: There is only one difference between Pro and base PS5. Pro runs at 120 Hz whereas base PS5 runs at 90 Hz.

name: Retrieval
extraInfo: The Pro version will have more detailed environments, higher quality RT reflections and a sharper resolution compared to the base PS5 version. All at a more stable 60fps.

name: Returnal
extraInfo: Pro has roughly 2.5x the resolution compared to base PS5, resulting in a very frequent internal resolution of 1728p max (infrequent DRS of 1350p min) that outputs to 4K (base PS5 is a fixed 1080p that reconstructs to 1440p before upscaling to a 4K checkerboard). This leads to a less noisy/grainy image with less aliasing/flickering, though some image instability remains. Both PS5 consoles have framerate dips into the low 50s, but this occurs less often on Pro, and even the largest dips are still in the VRR window. Technically, Returnal uses other forms of RT outside of audio. However, this is only for background calculations, not for visual improvements, so it's not listed.

name: Ride 6
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off MotoGP 25 as there's no public information about Ride 6's Pro enhancements. However, as both games are by Milestone, use Unreal Engine 5, and have a similar aesthetic/scope, MotoGP provides a good baseline of what to expect from Ride 6's upcoming February 2026 launch - 'During gameplay, Pro runs runs between 80-120fps regardless of track/weather effects, but is usually between 90-110fps. The actual rider/track are 4K-like, but background assets such as trees/railings/stands look soft and do shimmer. This suggest a relatively low internal resolution before outputting to 4K, which makes sense considering the high framerate target. Base PS5 looks slightly blurrier and only runs between 65-80fps, with rare ceilings of 95fps, but at least doesn't fall below 60fps.'

name: Rise Of The Ronin

modes.name: prioritize graphics + ray tracing
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR with RT reflections at a very unstable 60fps (usually around 45fps in actual gameplay).

modes.name: prioritize graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR with no RT. Slightly higher average framerate than prioritize graphics + RT mode.

modes.name: prioritize FPS
modes.description: 1070p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a nearly locked 60fps with no RT.

extraInfo: Both graphics modes' framerate fall far below the VRR limit for a majority of gameplay. You can cap the framerate to 30fps, but it has uneven frame pacing so these modes will feel choppy regardless of your setup. The superior RT reflections make little difference in this scenario because of the framerate issue. Prioritize FPS mode however runs great because it always remains in the VRR window, and even with the lower bound of its dynamic resolution scaling, Pro's PSSR renders a more clear/less aliased image than base PS5's FSR (even in its graphics modes). Especially with foliage which regularly fills the screen.

name: Road Cafe Simulator
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off Hole Digging Master as there's no public information about Road Cafe Simulator's Pro enhancements. However, as both games are by Nostra and have a similar aesthetic/scope, HDM provides a good baseline of what to expect from RCS - 'Both the Pro and base PS5 version are the same for all intents and purposes (the framerate is a locked 60fps on both for example). At best, Pro has a negligible increase in resolution that you'd find hard to notice even when looking at both versions side by side. Non-Pro enhanced games like Metaphor: ReFantazio showcase more significant improvements simply due to Pro's increased horsepower.'

name: RoadCraft

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-4K native DRS to 4K FSR3 at 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K FSR3 at 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 also uses dynamic resolution scaling. However, its lowest internal resolution is 720p in base PS5 performance mode and it can only reach up to 1440p in its quality mode. Pro is therefore much sharper as its rendering 2x the pixels when both PS5 consoles max out their resolution, but this is the only difference between them.

name: Rogue Flight

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 8K at a very stable 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a very stable 120fps.

extraInfo: According to Truant Pixel, outside of resolution/framerate increases compared to the same modes on base PS5, Pro also has 'additional small graphical touches'.

name: Rue Valley
extraInfo: Despite having the Pro Enhanced badge on the PSN Store, Owlcat has confirmed to me that Rue Valley has no unique Pro upgrades. It's the same experience on PC too.

name: Rush: Apex Edition
extraInfo: There is only one difference between Pro and base PS5. Pro runs at 120 Hz whereas base PS5 runs at 90 Hz.

name: Sanguis Luna
extraInfo: Pro renders at 4K/60fps. However, there's (seemingly) no aliasing solution implemented, so edges of assets like doors/windows etc are still very jagged. Other graphical settings are also mediocre, such as missing shadows on basic assets like books. Therefore, the impact of any potential upgrades from base PS5 to Pro is minimal.

name: Saros
extraInfo: *Despite the move from UE4 (Returnal) to UE5 (Saros), Returnal's performance still provides a good baseline of expectations. As according to DF, Saros's debut base PS5 gameplay looked like a highly customized version of UE5 (no Lumen, Nanite or VSMs). Therefore, Saros shouldn't struggle as much as other UE5 games. Especially as base PS5 ran Saros at 1080p/60fps - 'The Pro has roughly 2.5x the resolution compared to base PS5, resulting in a very frequent internal resolution of 1728p max (infrequent DRS of 1350p min) that outputs to 4K (base PS5 is a fixed 1080p that reconstructs to 1440p before upscaling to a 4K checkerboard). This leads to a less noisy/grainy image with less aliasing/flickering, though some image instability remains. Both PS5 consoles have framerate dips into the low 50s, but this occurs less often on Pro, and even the largest dips are still in the VRR window. Technically, Returnal uses other forms of RT outside of audio. However, this is only for background calculations.'

name: Satisfactory
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 have a 30fps quality mode, a 40fps balanced mode and a 60fps performance mode. Resolution lowers and certain graphical settings like LODs/GI will be worse as the framerate increases. However, both consoles still have look 4K-like image in performance mode and only ever dip below 60fps with very crazy factory builds. Pro has increased draw distance, enhanced volumetrics, improved ambient occlusion and more compared to the same mode on base PS5.

name: Sengoku Dynasty
extraInfo: Pro has a singular mode than runs at native 4K and a stable 60fps. However, certain assets like foliage as well as ground textures can look quite low-poly. There's also a noticeable amount of fizzle in reflections - specifically in large bodies of water. You can adjust FOV for both first and third-person mode, which could potentially cause a more unstable framerate at higher values. There's no public info about base PS5 performance, but it presumably renders below a native 4K, while still at 60fps.

name: Shredders
extraInfo: Base PS5 and Pro both achieve a nearly locked 60fps. However, Pro runs at 4K native compared to base PS5's 1440p, which is a 2x resolution increase.

name: Silent Hill 2
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 hardware and software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps with hardware-based RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS to 4K TSR. Somewhat stable 60fps (lows of high 40s) with software-based RT.

extraInfo: Pro quality mode uses superior hardware-based RT (clearer, more accurate/full reflections etc) compared to the software-based RT in both base PS5 modes. Both Pro modes also hit their target framerate more often than their base PS5 version and Pro performance mode has a higher base resolution. However, Pro's quality mode, despite a more 4K like image and better RT, has so much PSSR shimmer that base PS5 quality mode looks better with TSR. Bloober has confirmed that they're working with Konami on a patch which will hopefully improve the PSSR implementation or revert to TSR (as they did for performance). However, it's now been over 1 year and the update did not arrive alongside the Series X|S November 2025 launch. Hopefully, it arrives in time with the SH2 movie in January 2026, or with the rumored Born from a Wish DLC.

name: Silent Hill F
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen GI and reflections, as well as UE5's RT version of Virtual Shadow Maps
extraInfo: Pro has a singular mode that's 864p-1368p DRS to 1440p PSSR at 60fps. It's meant to combine base PS5 quality mode's higher visuals and 1080p-1440p resolution, but at base PS5's 60fps performance mode (which is 810p-1080p DRS to 1440p). However, Pro's poor PSSR implementation suffers from artifacting/strobing on assets like grass (seen in games at Pro's launch due to early versions of PSSR). Base PS5 uses UE5's TSR to upscale, resulting in quality mode looking superior, although Pro is sharper than its performance mode. Assets affected by PSSR are also mainly in the first area, so it isn't as distracting later on. Due to many factors (a language barrier maybe preventing the issue reaching NeoBards/months since launch without a mention of a fix etc), DF believes it's also unlikely PSSR issues get patched. Finally, both Pro and base PS5 performance mode run at a stable 60fps except for mid 50s traversal stutters in open areas and base PS5 quality mode is a locked 30fps.

name: Skull And Bones
extraInfo: Pro combines elements of base PS5 quality mode (4K native with RTGI at 30fps) and performance mode (720p fixed to 1440p FSR2 at 60fps) into one mode (Approx 1440p at 60fps with RTGI). In practice, Pro's framerate is not a locked 60fps on either land or sea, but only dips to 55fps-58fps which is well within the VRR window. The resolution is a clear improvement over base PS5 performance mode, but reflections remain noticeably low-res. Since screen space reflections dominate the ocean surfaces, the overall visual quality still falls short of Pro expectations. Finally, the RTGI implementation is identical to the base PS5 quality mode - limited to the player's ship.

name: Slitterhead
extraInfo: A native 4K and more stable 60fps compared to base PS5, especially in later boss fights. *Technical information is aggregated off anecdotal remarks by gamers who have completed Slitterhead, not from a primary source or established secondary source like Digital Foundry as none exist at time of writing.

name: Smash Drums

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 120fps with higher resolution and better VFX compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 120fps native.

extraInfo: Whereas base PS5 is only 90fps in its fidelity mode and 120fps performance mode, Pro is 120fps in both.

name: Sniper Elite: Resistance
extraInfo: Both PS5 consoles have dynamic resolution scaling, but Pro hits native 4K often, which is extremely rare on base PS5. Base PS5 also renders a low of 1296p often when that's less than 1% on Pro. However, all versions (Xbox/PC too) are poorly aliased, so resolution gaps are less noticeable than in other games because there's so much shimmer regardless. Pro's 60fps is locked aside from some effect-heavy explosions. This is more stable than base PS5, which can drop to low 50s in general gameplay.

name: Spider-Man 1 Remastered
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 fidelity mode (all RT/more asset density etc). 4K at locked 30fps/40fps for 60 Hz/120 Hz screens.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 75-90fps with VRR. Fidelity mode level of image quality (RT/increased pedestrian density etc).

extraInfo: Performance Pro (which Insomniac recommends) now has RT unlike base PS5 performance mode. Fidelity mode is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, especially in areas like reflections, but its not at 60fps and PSSR still resolves more detail than seen on base PS5.

name: Spider-Man: Miles Morales
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 fidelity mode (all RT/more asset density etc). 4K at locked 30fps/40fps for 60 Hz/120 Hz screens.

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 75-90fps with VRR. Fidelity mode level of image quality (RT/increased pedestrian density etc).

extraInfo: Performance Pro (which Insomniac recommends) now has RT unlike base PS5 performance mode. Fidelity mode is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, especially in areas like reflections, but its not at 60fps and PSSR still resolves more detail than seen on base PS5.

name: Spider-Man 2
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows (key light) and ambient occlusion

modes.name: fidelity pro
modes.description: 4K PSSR at locked 30fps/40fps for 60 Hz/120 Hz screens, or usually around mid 50s with VRR. Highest quality RT (explained below).

modes.name: performance pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or usually around 70fps with VRR. Base PS5's fidelity mode level of RT quality.

extraInfo: Fidelity Pro is sharper/more stable than Performance Pro, but PSSR in Performance Pro still resolves more detail than the upscaler seen in any base PS5 mode. Fidelity Pro RT key light shadows now includes very distant buildings, RT reflections are full resolution (50% in Performance Pro) and RTAO has more contact shadows, adding depth to assets all over the screen. RT types can be toggled on/off which affects VRR framerate approx +- 10. Draw distance/distant reflections are also improved over Performance Pro (which is at base PS5 Fidelity mode), e.g. more onscreen distant objects like trees. Graphics settings are equivalent to PC's high/very high.

name: Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 4K at a basically locked 60fps. Drops to 1440p in 4-player split screen.

extraInfo: Base PS5 is 4K/30fps in its graphics mode and 1080p/60fps in its performance mode.

name: Split Fiction
extraInfo: Base PS5 has dynamic resolution scaling, which internally ranges between 1523p-1800p, then upscales to 4K. Whereas Pro's resolution is native 4K. Fortunately, both consoles run at a locked 60fps. Finally, despite being on Unreal Engine 5, Pro (and even PC) doesn't use any form of RT, including UE5's Lumen.

name: Stalker 2: Heart Chornobyl

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1662p to 4K TSR at a basically locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1270p DRS to 4K TSR at a relatively stable 60fps. Worse graphical settings (LODs etc) than quality mode.

extraInfo: Pro has improved shadow quality and resolution, enhanced global illumination, higher-quality reflections, improved volumetric fog, and enhanced volumetric cloud rendering over base PS5. Both consoles have a performance and quality mode, but only Pro renders at 4K in both modes. Base PS5 performance mode's 864p-1152p DRS to 1440p TSR looks noticeably blurrier, with a slightly more unstable 60fps. However, its 1440p to 4K TSR/basically locked 30fps quality mode performs similar to Pro outside of graphical settings and a slightly lower internal resolution. Finally, GSC are planning to update the engine from UE5 5.1.1 to 5.5.4 in 2026, which will significantly optimize features like Lumen/Virtual Shadow Maps.

name: Star Wars Jedi: Survivor
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, global illumination and ambient occlusion

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1584p to 4K PSSR. Locked 30fps with more detailed RT implementation compared to performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 900p average DRS to 1800p PSSR. Nearly locked at 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Pro now has the latest PSSR version, which is far less noisy/unstable/shimmery than the original, objectively ugly patch. Flickering in foliage and RT reflections are especially improved and is now on par with FSR on base PS5. PSSR is also sharper than FSR (and even DLSS on PC) in motion, though softest in stills. Pro performance mode also brings back RT that's not in the base PS5 version, but the implementation is still worse than either PS5's quality mode.

name: Star Wars Outlaws
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality pro
modes.description: 900p-1152p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR3 at a nearly locked 60fps.

modes.name: quality
modes.description: Sharper than quality pro (1512p-1800p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR3) but at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Visual quality downgraded compared to quality but now at a locked 40fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lowest visual quality of all modes. 720p-936p DRS to 4K PSSR/FSR at a nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: All modes can use either PSSR or FSR3 for upscaling. FSR looks clearer/less noisy with assets like foliage in stills, but the difference is miniscule now that Outlaws updated its PSSR implementation, which beats FSR in clarity/stability in motion. Quality mode is the only one with stable RT. Quality/balanced/performance are all the legacy modes from base PS5 (which only uses FSR), but will run at the higher DRS bounds (1800p for quality etc) more often, with a more stable framerate, due to Pro's extra power.

name: Stellar Blade

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1800p to 4K PSSR. A very nearly locked 80fps on 120 Hz screens and 60fps on 60 Hz screens.

modes.name: pro max
modes.description: 4K TAA at 50-60fps.

modes.name: prioritize resolution
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 quality mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 balanced mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

modes.name: prioritize performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 performance mode. See below for reasons why it's redundant.

extraInfo: The legacy modes from base PS5 are still present, but like Pro Max mode, they use TAA. The 80fps Pro mode is the only one that uses PSSR. The PSSR implementation is far better than TAA at de-noising/sharpening/stabilizing/de-shimmering the image. So even with a lower base resolution (1800p), Pro mode looks better than the native 4K TAA in Pro Max, let alone the legacy modes that max out at 60fps. With the best image quality and highest framerate, Pro mode makes all the others redundant.

name: Stunt Paradise
extraInfo: While both base PS5 and Pro run at a basically locked 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro renders at 4K, which is a 2.25x increase in resolution.

name: Stunt Paradise 2
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off Stunt Paradise 1. However, due to Brinemedia's history with Pro games (including Stunt Paradise 1), we can be confident that these figures will be the case at launch - 'While both base PS5 and Pro run at a basically locked 120fps, base PS5 is limited to 1440p. Pro renders at 4K, which is a 2.25x increase in resolution.'

name: Subside
extraInfo: Both base PS5 and Pro run at 90 Hz with no reprojection. However, Pro has dynamic shadows (which A2D claim is the most significant improvement) and an edge blur effect. Pro also has a 2.5x foveated resolution increase compared to the 2.25x increase on base PS5.

name: Sword Of The Sea
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 have a singular mode that runs at 60fps. Pro's framerate is more stable than base PS5, but can still dip below when multiple effects are onscreen. Most of these dips should however stay within the VRR window. Both Pro and base PS5 also upscale to 4K as the final output resolution, but the internal resolution is noticeably higher on Pro and results in a sharper image.

name: Test Drive Unlimited: SC

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p at a nearly locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 graphics mode only renders at 1440p, which is Pro's internal resolution before upscaling to 4K. In practice, the upscale makes little difference as the internal resolution is so high. Base PS5 performance mode is only 1080p, which makes a bigger difference in clarity between the consoles equivalent modes. Pro is also able to achieve its target framerate more often.

name: The Alters
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 1440p DRS to 4K TSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lower DRS, but at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Performance mode's lower internal resolution can lead to things like slightly more ghosting and more edge instability. However, the image quality between the 2 modes are still very close. Base PS5 performs very similar to Pro, with the only difference being lower internal DRS bounds in each mode.

name: The Callisto Protocol

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 6K to 8K TAAU at locked 30fps with RT. Can be down-sampled back to 4K for a clearer image on 4K screens.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 4K TAAU at a very stable 40fps with RT. Higher internal resolution than performance mode.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1296p-1440p DRS to 4K TAAU at a nearly locked 60fps with RT.

extraInfo: Performance mode has the biggest jump from base PS5 as that performance mode has no RT and a more unstable 60fps. RT quality is the same on Pro and base PS5, so there isn't much difference in the quality modes outside of resolution.

name: The Crew Motorfest
extraInfo: Looks much more detailed than even base PS5's 30fps resolution mode due to more objects, decals, vegetation and crowds. However, there is no introduction of RT. The 60fps is also locked at 1700p (approx) to 4K PSSR, which is a big improvement over base PS5's 1080p in performance and even its 30fps mode which renders at 1440p.

name: The Elder Scrolls IV: OR
pageTitle: The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen global illumination and reflections with dynamic shadows

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p-2016p DRS (usually around 1620p) to 4K at a locked, but improperly paced 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1188p-1620p DRS to 4K at a very unstable 60fps that regularly falls below VRR window. Internal resolution/framerate dips lower when outside.

extraInfo: Pro performance mode has slightly improved draw distance/lighting than the base PS5 modes. Resolution and framerate in Pro performance mode are slightly increased compared to base PS5 (internal res can drop to 900p). There's no HDR and quality mode is improperly paced everywhere. No matter the console, performance gets worse if booting up from rest mode, cycling through saves or a continuous playthrough due to memory leak and needs a fresh start of the app to fix. These issues are still present as of patch 1.2/Aug 2025.

name: The Elders Scrolls Online
extraInfo: Pro uses variable rate shading to render native 4K at 60fps. This one Pro mode combines the 2 modes on base PS5 (a 4K/30fps fidelity mode with higher graphical settings such as shadows, textures and ambient occlusion etc, and a 1440p/60fps performance mode). Pro also gets the higher graphical settings seen in base PS5 fidelity mode.

name: The Finals
extraInfo: The only difference between Pro and base PS5 is a resolution increase (base PS5 has 1440p-4K DRS). General gameplay looks slightly sharper on Pro as it renders 4K more often, with a more stable 60fps due to the extra GPU horsepower. RTGI quality is the same on both consoles and neither have an option for 120fps.

name: The First Berserker: K

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p (likely) to 4K at a relatively stable 60fps. At least when it matters most (see extra info).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Around 1220p (approx) to 4K at a locked 60fps.

extraInfo: Quality mode holds at 60fps for the majority of combat. It can dip when lots of graphical effects are onscreen, but still stays above the 48fps VRR window. However, it can fall below that threshold in cutscenes. You can remove the framerate limit, but the game recommends that you keep it at 60fps or below.

name: The First Descendant
rtTypes: Ray traced shadows, reflections on translucent and opaque surfaces, ambient occlusion and radiance cache

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K PSSR at 30fps, or up to 60fps with frame generation on. Has all RT if turned on.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: Same as fidelity mode, but aims for 40fps via a lower internal resolution before upscaling to 4K PSSR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p PSSR at 60fps, which is achieved more often with frame gen on. Has all RT except for RT shadows and translucent surface reflections.

extraInfo: One of the few Pro games to combine PSSR's upscaling with AMD's FSR frame generation, whereas base PS5 uses FSR for upscaling. You can toggle both RT and frame gen on/off in all modes. Frame gen increases framerates, but isn't recommended in any mode as the base framerate is too low, resulting in too much input lag.

name: The Last Of Us Part I

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70-90fps with VRR.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 4K at a locked 30fps, 40fps with a 120 Hz display, or 50-60fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 60fps, or around 80-110fps with VRR.

extraInfo: The fidelity and performance modes are the same as on base PS5, but with VRR enabled, there's usually around a 25fps advantage on Pro. PSSR in Pro mode looks much sharper (especially foliage) than performance mode's TAA. There's also less noise/anti-aliasing in motion and improved SSR compared to legacy modes, but fidelity mode is still very close in image quality and some reflections can even look better. Finally, PSSR beats FSR in the PC version and comes very close to DLSS.

name: The Last Of Us Part II

modes.name: pro
modes.description: 1440p to 4K PSSR at a locked 60fps, or around 70-90fps with VRR.

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 4K at a locked 30fps, 40fps with a 120 Hz display, or 50-60fps with VRR.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Legacy base PS5 mode. 1440p to 4K TAA at a locked 60fps, or around 80-110fps with VRR.

extraInfo: The fidelity and performance modes are the same as on base PS5, but with VRR enabled, there's usually around a 25fps advantage on Pro. PSSR in Pro mode looks much sharper (especially foliage) than performance mode's TAA. There's also less noise/anti-aliasing in motion and improved SSR compared to legacy modes, but fidelity mode is still very close in image quality and some reflections can even look better. PSSR beats FSR in the PC version and comes very close to DLSS. Overall, Pro mode is around PC Ultra settings except for shadows, which is a tier below.

name: The Outer Worlds 2
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 software-based Lumen reflections and global illumination

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p-4K DRS to 4K TSR at a basically locked 30fps.

modes.name: balanced
modes.description: 1440p-1800p DRS to 4K TSR at a basically locked 40fps. Visual quality mainly of performance mode except foliage GI).

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1620p to 4K at a basically locked 60fps. Lower quality graphics settings (check extra info).

extraInfo: Obsidian has removed the bad PSSR implementation seen at launch and reverted back to TSR, which results in better performance gains, less noisy RT and a sharper image on Pro. Performance mode has less, more static foliage (at close distances) and lower quality (and therefore less realistic) UE5 Lumen/Virtual Shadow Maps. The lower internal resolution also leads to a noticeably softer/less stable image. Base PS5 has slightly worse framerate stability and internal resolutions compared to the equivalent mode on Pro, which leads to more instability/breakup - especially in performance mode.

name: The Outlast Trials
extraInfo: The RT reflections toggle is exclusive to Pro, whereas base PS5 only has screen space reflections. While Pro's RT can cause the resolution to dip slightly below native 4K in more complex scenes, the difference is basically imperceptible even when directly comparing, let alone in general gameplay. Otherwise, both Pro and base PS5 are native 4K at a locked 60fps when using SSR (screen space reflections).

name: The Precinct
extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5 render at native 4K with a locked 30fps. However, Pro has numerous improved graphical settings over base PS5. These include, but aren't limited to, lighting, textures, shadows (resolution & quality), reflections, animation, effects, and crowds. Pro's graphical settings are equivalent to high/very high on PC. Finally, Fallen Tree Games has confirmed there's no plans for a 60fps mode due to CPU limitations on both base and Pro.

name: The Rogue Prince Of Persia
extraInfo: While the launch trailer on PlayStation's YouTube channel states that The Rogue Prince of Persia is Pro enhanced, this is unlikely to be the case. The game isn't marked as such on the PSN store, and there's no mention from another primary source about enhancements. If it's Pro enhanced, any differences between it and base PS5 are so small that they're imperceptible even when comparing up close. Let alone the average gamer just playing on Pro at a regular viewing distance (both run at 4K for instance). Pro probably maintains its 120fps framerate more often, but VRR would completely negate this advantage at this framerate target.

name: The Sinking City
rtTypes: Unreal Engine 5 Lumen software-based global illumination/reflections

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1440p DRS to 4K TSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Lower DRS at a stable 60fps. Worse Lumen quality.

extraInfo: Performance mode's lower internal resolution can lead to things like slightly more ghosting and more edge instability. However, the image difference is mainly with the worse Lumen GI and missing reflections on assets like railings. Base PS5 performs very similar to Pro (also has Lumen/4K textures etc), with the only difference (likely) being lower internal DRS bounds in each mode.

name: Tides Of Annihilation
extraInfo: Despite releasing in 2026, EGG has confirmed a surprising amount about the Pro version via the PlayStation Blog. There will be a Pro exclusive 'enhanced mode' that utilizes PSSR to achieve all the expected Pro upgrades. This includes a higher resolution, RT, and improved image fidelity, all at 60fps. The most recent February 2025 trailer suggests an internal resolution of 576p-1080p DRS (1080p is far more often) and there's drops to around 35fps, but ToA's launch is around a year away leaving plenty of time for optimization. Using Pro footage for trailers so far from release does inspire confidence that it will get the optimization needed for a great 'enhanced mode'.

name: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3/4

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1662p to 4K at a basically locked 60fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p-1552p DRS to 4K at a basically locked 120fps.

extraInfo: Both Pro and base PS5's quality modes have an internal resolution that's usually at 1662p. While Pro's performance mode can have a 1080p base resolution at its lowest, base PS5 can drop to as low as 635p to reach 120fps. There can also be some screen tearing in the performance modes on both consoles. All modes can drop a frame, but it's a rare occurrence that only lasts a second.

name: TopSpin 2K25
extraInfo: Pro now runs cutscenes/replays at 60fps instead of the 30fps on base PS5. This is the only upgrade as there's no resolution/gameplay differences between Pro and base PS5 (4K/60fps on both).

name: Truck Driver: TAD
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, ambient occlusion and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity pro 30fps
modes.description: Prioritizes resolution over framerate. Dynamic 4K PSSR at locked 30fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: fidelity pro unlocked
modes.description: Prioritizes framerate over resolution. Dynamic 4K PSSR at 60/120fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: performance RT pro
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p DRS, but with RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p DRS. No RT.

extraInfo: All modes use dynamic resolutions scaling. PSSR implementation produces much better assets, including moving ones like foliage, compared to TSR on base PS5. The resolution is also higher and there's better shadows regardless of mode. Pro also uses hardware accelerated RT reflections, RTAO and RTGI compared to the inferior software based RT on base PS5. Finally, the performance RT mode is exclusive to PS5 Pro.

name: Truck Driver: TDC
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, ambient occlusion and global illumination

modes.name: fidelity pro 30fps
modes.description: Prioritizes resolution over framerate. Dynamic 4K PSSR at locked 30fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: fidelity pro unlocked
modes.description: Prioritizes framerate over resolution. Dynamic 4K PSSR at 60/120fps. Has improved shadows, lighting and draw distance compared to performance modes. Also has RTAO/GI/reflections.

modes.name: performance RT pro
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p DRS, but with RT.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: Favors higher framerates (40/60/120fps) over resolution, which is 1080p-1440p DRS. No RT.

extraInfo: *All tech information is based off Kyodai's Truck Driver: The American Dream. The only aspect that's been confirmed is that Pro will use hardware RT, whereas base PS5 is using software RT. - 'All modes use dynamic resolutions scaling. PSSR implementation produces much better assets, including moving ones like foliage, compared to TSR on base PS5. The resolution is also higher and there's better shadows regardless of mode. Pro also uses hardware accelerated RT reflections, RTAO and RTGI compared to the inferior software based RT on base PS5. Finally, the performance RT mode is exclusive to PS5 Pro.'

name: UFL
extraInfo: Pro runs at a locked 60fps and native 4K. The display options are very similar to what you seen in FIFA/EA FC games. Therefore, there's no options for things like 120fps.

name: Undisputed
extraInfo: According to Steel City's patch notes, Pro has 'revamped lighting and improved gameplay graphics'. This likely means an 120fps option isn't in the cards. Despite the revamped lighting, Undisputed still doesn't support HDR - a feature the would drastically improve lighting with zero impact to performance, even on base PS5.

name: Until Dawn

modes.name: fidelity
modes.description: 4K at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1440p to 4K at a stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Until Dawn allows you to render at 2.39:1 ratio for a more cinematic look with black bars but a wider viewing angle, or the usual 16:9. This doesn't affect resolution or framerate. Base PS5 also has a fidelity and performance mode that targets the same framerate but at lower resolutions.

name: Vampire Survivors
extraInfo: A Gamespot article states that Poncle claims the Pro is capable of 9000p resolution (compared to 4K on base PS5) and even more vampires. However, Gamespot doesn't cite any source for this claim, nor could I source Poncle's words myself. At the very least, Pro maintains 60fps more consistently - a framerate target that isn't always achieved on base PS5 in later stages/weapon combinations.

name: War Thunder
extraInfo: Pro has DRS that can render up to 4K native (which it regularly does), whereas base PS5 only renders at 1080p when aiming for 120fps. Base ps5 only runs at 60fps when rendering at 4K. According to Gaijin, Pro also gets 'more improvements and additional optimization'. However, there's still a good amount of shimmer on assets like railings despite the up to 4x increase in resolution.

name: Wanderer: TFOF
extraInfo: There's currently no Pro patch, but Mighty Eyes's roadmap confirmed that one is coming sometime after July 2025. This will come with exclusive 'visual enhancements and effects to bring more fidelity and realism to each world', so expect more than just a resolution bump. A 60fps resolution mode that uses 'repositional' reprojection is also coming to both Pro and base PS5. Considering Pro's extra power and drop in framerate, resolution mode should be able to push PSVR2's screen to its maximum resolution of 2000 x 2040 per eye. Finally, it's currently unknown if an 120fps native mode will also be added with these enhancements.

name: Warframe
extraInfo: There's no strict quality/performance modes, nor can you go above 60fps. Instead, Warframe's menus are very PC-like in UI. For example, you can toggle graphical settings of aspects like particle quality and volumetric fog. You can also toggle PSSR on/off. If PSSR is on and all graphical settings so to their highest, the framerate is a basically locked 60fps. If toggled off/no upscaler used, it will rarely maintain 60fps, but will stay above the 48fps VRR window for the vast majority of gameplay.

name: Warhammer 40,000: DT
extraInfo: Base PS5 has a performance mode at 1440p/60fps (936p internal) and quality mode at 4K/30fps (1440p internal). Pro renders at 4K/60fps (1270p internal) and looks sharper (especially in motion) than even base PS5 quality mode, despite the lower internal resolution, due to PSSR. Pro's framerate is also more stable in areas where base PS5 isn't, but can still dip below 60fps at higher difficulties due to more enemies onscreen. Pro also runs most graphical settings equivalent to 'high' on PC.

name: Warhammer 40,000: RT

modes.name: graphics
modes.description: 4K native at a nearly locked 30fps.

modes.name: performance
modes.description: 1080p at a relatively stable 60fps.

extraInfo: Base PS5 only has a singular 1080p/30fps mode as it can't render Rogue Trader at native 4K. Pro also has a more stable framerate (though not perfect) in both modes.

name: Warhammer 40,000: SM2

modes.name: quality
modes.description: 1080p-2160p DRS to 4K PSSR at a locked 30fps.

modes.name: speed
modes.description: 1080p-1440p DRS to 4K PSSR at a relatively stable 60fps. Drops to around 50fps in more chaotic scenes.

extraInfo: Base PS5 also has dynamic resolution scaling, but instead uses FSR2 to upscale its modes and have a lower base resolution before upscaling (e.g. 720p for speed mode). The result is a noticeably blurrier image compared to the Pro versions, especially in motion where PSSR excels. Pro also hits 60fps more often, though it's still not ideal as it can fall out of the VRR window.

name: Weed & Greed
extraInfo: *All tech information is based off Hole Digging Master as there's no public information about Weed & Greed's Pro enhancements. However, as both games are by Nostra and have a similar aesthetic/scope, HDM provides a good baseline of what to expect from W&G - 'Both the Pro and base PS5 version are the same for all intents and purposes (the framerate is a locked 60fps on both for example). At best, Pro has a negligible increase in resolution that you'd find hard to notice even when looking at both versions side by side. Non-Pro enhanced games like Metaphor: ReFantazio showcase more significant improvements simply due to Pro's increased horsepower.'

name: Where Winds Meet
extraInfo: Only Pro can toggle on RT reflections (it should come to PC eventually) and it greatly improves reflections in areas like bodies of water. RT doesn't significantly impact either resolution or framerate, which is a 50-60fps on both consoles at the beginning of the game, but gets progressively worse (dips to 30s) in later, more built up/populated regions (especially on base PS5). Pro's 1440p internal resolution and great PSSR 4K upscale implementation results in a 4K-like image. Foliage (which can be all over the screen) is especially sharp and looks far more dithered on base PS5's 1080p to 4K upscale, although Pro also still suffers from pop in.

name: Wolverine
rtTypes: Ray traced reflections, shadows and ambient occlusion (based off Spider-Man 2)

modes.name: fidelity pro
